"At both sites, the students' regular classroom teachers
agreed to participate in the experiment as either Mastery or
conventional teachers.
Since they were not to enhance cues, participation,
reinforcement, or feedback and correction beyond what they
could naturally provide in the group setting, teachers in
the conventional conditions required no training. T"
"The Mastery teachers were familiarized with the
instructional materials, formative tests, and corrective
materials. The corrective process was explained to these
teachers in detail, and their questions and problems were
discussed. The construction and use of the formative tests
and corrective materials were been discussed in the sections

ing Students' Cognitive Achievement" (pp. 64-65).[¬e]"

"Training of Observers and the
Monitoring of the
Instructional Treatments[¬e]"

Page 94:
[¬s]"training. Observers were trained to execute two tasks: to
estimate time-on task, to evaluate the quality of the
instruction. The last task served a dual purpose: first,
it determined whether the treatments were implemented as
designed, and second, it served as a basis for "quality con­
trol", so that appropriate corrective action could be taken
if a teacher or tutor strayed badly from the design."
"In training the observers to estimate time on-task, we
began by discussing various behaviors which indicate whether
a student is on-task or off-task. Observers were provided
with a list of these behaviors. Observers visited at least
one class before the experiment began, observing time on-
task according to the procedures described in the section
"Time On-task" (p. 61). Where possible, pairs observed the
same classroom, in order to provide a "reliability check"
for each other's observations."
"The training of the observers to monitor the instruc­
tional treatments began with a discussion, led by the exper­
imenter, of the theoretical background of instructional
quality."
"This discussion included the objectives of the
instructional treatments and the behaviors of teachers,
tutors, and students expected in these treatments. Observ­
ers were then introduced to the "Components Observation
Instrument", which they were to use in monitoring the qual­
ity of the instruction. This instruments has been described
in in the section "Instructional Processing Behaviors" (pp.[¬e]"

[¬s]"61-62). Before the experiment began, observers visited at
least one class, where possible in pairs, and used the
instrument to evaluate the quality of the instruction.[¬e]"

Page 89:
[¬s]"blue-collar suburb of a large midwestern city[¬e]"

Page 13:
[¬s]"The subject taught in this research was probability.
Probability was chosen because it was a new topic for the
students in our sample, because attractive commercial mater­
ials were available, and because a technical, sequential
subject was appropriate for studying lower and higher mental
processes.[¬e]"

Page 62:
[¬s]"Students' specific affective entry characteristics are
their interests, attitudes, and self-concepts in regard to a
particular subject, in this case probability. These spe­
cific affective characteristics were measured, at the begin­
ning of each instructional task, on the Affective Survey
Instrument"
"To assess students' interests, attitudes, and self-con­
cepts in regard to probability, the experimenter prepared a
number of items. These items were rated by two judges. If[¬e]"

Page 63:
[¬s]"both judges agreed that an item fairly assessed affect
toward probability, the item was included on the affective
instruments. We estimated students' interest in probablity
from their desire to learn more about it. We estimated stu­
dents' attitude toward probability from the value they
placed on it in comparison to other subjects. Lastly, we
estimated students' self-concept in relation to probability
from the way they saw themselves as competent or incompetent
learners of this subject.[¬e]"

Page 67:
[¬s]"Rate of Learning
The formulation of rate of learning for this model has
been discussed in the section "A Conceptual Framework for
Analyzing Students' Achievement and Their Use of Time" (pp.
40-43). Here, we need only remind ourselves that our learn­
ing rates estimate the time students would need to learn a
task to a level of 100 percent correct."
"For this research, students' learning processes
included their use of instructional time and certain of
their mental and physical behaviors during instruction[¬e]"

Page 68:
[¬s]"Time on-task is the amount of instructional time stu­
dents are actively engaged in learning. Time on-task was
estimated from observations of the students' behaviors dur­
ing instruction."
"Observers scanned the classroom at the
beginning, middle, and towards the end of an instructional
period, focussing on each child for about 5 seconds and then
rating whether that child was on-task or off-task. After
completing one scan, the observer paused and began another.
Using this process, during a single instructional period a
number of observations were made of each learner. Details
of the training of the observers will be given in the Design
section (pp. 86-88)."
"Instructional Processing
Behaviors
During the learning activities, students' behaviors
were monitored both by self-report and by observation. On
the Components Checklist, adapted from Hecht's (1977)
"Activities Checklist", students reported the following:
(1) whether they understood the instructional cues; (2)
whether they participated frequently in the learning activi­
ties; (3) whether they were rewarded during their learning;
(4) whether they received adequate feedback and correction.[¬e]"

Page 72:
[¬s]"Affective Outcomes
This research monitored three dimensions of students’
affect regarding probability: interests, attitudes, and
self-concepts. We estimated students' interests in prob­
ability from their desire to learn more about it. We esti­
mated students' attitudes toward probability by how highly
it was valued in comparison with other subjects."
"We esti­
mated students' self-concepts as learners of probability by
how highly they rated their performance in probability. The
affective instruments were described in detail in the sec­
tion "Generalized and Specific Affective Entry Characteris­
tics" (pp. 55-56). Affect was measured before instruction
began, at the beginning of each instructional task, and
after the students were informed of their final achievement.[¬e]"

Page 56:
[¬s]"The conceptual framework for this research was largely
derived from Bloom’s (1976) theory of school learning. In
Bloom's theory, students' cognitive and affective develop­
ment is determined by the interactions of certain of the
students' characteristics with the quality of the instruc­
tion. Bloom's model considers both the affective and the
cognitive characteristics which students bring to a new
course of learning. Instructional quality is the degree to
which cues, participation, reinforcement, and feedback and
correction are appropriate to the specific needs of each
learner.[¬e]"

Page 57:
[¬s]"This research departed slightly from Bloom's formula­
tion of the process of school learning. We share with Bloom
the specification that students' learning processes are
functions of the instructional conditions. However, in our
formulation students' learning processes are the sole proxi­
mal cause of their achievement.[¬e]"

Codes.AdditionalText: All fifth grade (as per coding instructions for this study).

ItemAttributeFullTextDetails.Text:
Page 65:
[¬s]"At the end of each instructional unit, the Mastery stu­
dents completed a formative test. This test indicated to
the teacher and to the students what the students still had
to learn in order to master the unit at a level of 80 per­
cent correct. Students who did not attain the mastery cri­
terion on the first formative test were assigned to correct
their errors. This was done with the help of instructional
materials, constructed by the experimenter, which explained
the solution to each item and provided additional explana­
tion and examples of the idea tested by each item.[¬e]"

Codes.AdditionalText: No indication of grouping by attainment.

ItemAttributeFullTextDetails.Text:
Page 89:
[¬s]"At both sites, stu­
dents were randomly assigned to treatments.[¬e]"

Page 65:
[¬s]"Students who did not attain the mastery cri­
terion on the first formative test were assigned to correct
their errors. This was done with the help of instructional
materials, constructed by the experimenter, which explained
the solution to each item and provided additional explana­
tion and examples of the idea tested by each item."
"The formative tests were corrected by aides assigned to
the Mastery classrooms; these aides recorded the students'
scores and the items missed by each student. Items missed
by more than half the class were explained by the teacher to
the group. After that, individual students used the correc­
tive materials to help understand the items they got wrong."
"Following this first round of testing and correction,
students who had not initially reached mastery were retested
on the items they needed to reach mastery. Students who
still had not reached mastery on this second test repeated
the corrective activities as time allowed. One instruc­
tional period was alloted to all testing and correction.[¬e]"

Page 66:
[¬s]"Under the teacher’s supervision, students who reached
mastery on the first formative test assisted students who
had not reached mastery on the first or the second formative
tests[¬e]"

Page 70:
[¬s]"The model predicts that the quality of the instruction
detrmines students’ lower and higher mental processes.
Lower mental processes were estimated from the students'
performance on test items at the Knowledge or Comprehension
levels of the Taxonomy. A Knowledge item required the stu­
dent to identify a term, fact, rule, or principle, or to use
these elements to solve problems similar to ones encountered
during the instruction. A Comprehension item required the
student to translate information from verbal to quantitative
form."
"Higher mental processes were estimated from the stu­
dents' performance on items at the Application or Analysis
levels of the Taxonomy. An Application item required the
student to use the relevant terms, facts, rules, or princi­
ples to solve a problem which was different from the ones
encountered during instructon. An Analysis item required
the student to determine what additional information beyond
what was given was necessary to develop a solution to a
problem.[¬e]"

Page 71:
[¬s]"Formative tests were constructed according to proce­
dures recommended in the Handbook for Formative and Summa-
tive Evaluation of Student Learning (Bloom, Hastings, and
Madaus, 1971). The content of each instructional unit was
classified, in a table of specifications, according to what
mental processes were expected of the students. Items for
the formative tests were chosen from the most important ele­
ments in the table of specification."
"The validity of the items was established in two steps.
First, two judges rated whether each item appropriately rep­
resented the content of the instructional unit. Next, the
judges rated, on the basis of the content and objectives of
the instructional unit, whether the item was a lower or
higher mental process item. An item was included on a for­
mative test for a given unit only if both judges agreed on
the cognitive level of the item, and that the item appropri­
ately represented the content of the instructional unit"
"A second pool of items was developed on the most impor­
tant content and objectives of the course. An item was
included in this pool only if two judges agreed first on the
cognitive level of the item, and second that the item repre­
sented the content of the course. For each item selected
for the summative test, a similar item was selected for the
retention test. For all students, the final lower and
higher mental process score was estimated from the summative[¬e]"

Page 72:
[¬s]"test. The score for lower and higher mental process reten­
tion was estimated from the retention test[¬e]"

Page 65:

the teacher and to the students what the students still had
to learn in order to master the unit at a level of 80 per­
cent correct.[¬e]"

References.Title: Students’ potential for learning contrasted under tutorial and group approaches to instruction.
References.Abstract: One reason for chronically low achievement is that, under conventional instruction, the teacher's time and attention are so divided among a group of students that the specific needs of each student can not be met. Under these conditions, students' learning is so full of errors that their achievement is far below their potential. Our thesis was that students' potential for learning will be developed to very high levels when instruction is fully adapted to each student's specific needs. To explore this idea, we contrasted students' cognitive and affective learning under tutoring, Mastery Learning, and conventional group instruction. Approximately 260 fourth and fifth graders participated in the three replications of this study. In each replication, students were randomly assigned to learn probability under one of the three instructional arrangements. Tutors were undergraduate education students in pre-professional training. The Mastery and the conventional conditions were managed by the students' regular mathematics teachers. Students' cognitive and affective characteristics were very similar at the beginning of instruction. By the end of three weeks, dramatic differences had emerged. The final achievement of the average tutored student was at a level above approximately 95 percent of the control students. The final achievement of the average Mastery student was at a level above approximately 85 percent of the control students. In addition, the high levels of final achievement were retained at high levels under tutoring and Mastery Learning. These differences held for both lower and higher mental processes, as defined by the Taxonomy of Educational Objectives. What is especially noteworthy, under tutoring and Mastery Learning low aptitude students achieved at higher levels than students of high aptitude who received conventional instruction. These findings have many implications for schooling. Perhaps the most important implication is that the student's potential for learning can not be accurately predicted from the student's home environment, from tests of the student's aptitude, or even from the student's prior achievement under conventional instruction. The student's full potential for learning can properly be estimated only when the student is learning under the most effective instructional conditions that can be devised.
References.Comments: This study provides results for 2 different grades (grade 4 & 5) and 3 different sites (grade 4 site 1, grade 5 site 1 & grade 5 site 2), three different groups (tutoring, mastery, conventional) and different sections of the tests used. Please compare the mastery learning vs. the conventional group on Site 1, Grade 5 focusing on FT1A, FT2A and FT3A vs post-test.
References.QuickCitation: Burke Arthur Joseph (1983) Students’ potential for learning contrasted under tutorial and group approaches to instruction.. , .

Page 66:
[¬s]"Mastery Learning may be understood as an attempt to
remedy, in a single period of correction, errors which have
developed and remained unremedied over many periods of
instruction, so that students become well-prepared for sub­
sequent learning tasks.[¬e]"

Page 76:
[¬s]"Mastery Learning provides
feedback and correction to help most students learn each
unit at a high level. As a result, Mastery students are
adequately prepared for subsequent learning tasks. Under
these conditions, the student's time on-task and rate of
learning are likely to be quite high. Finally, since the
instruction brings the student to mastery, achievement
becomes less predicted by prior cognitive characteristics
such as aptitude or intelligence.[¬e]"

Page 78:
[¬s]"Under Mastery Learning, the student receives feedback
and correction to learn the first task at a high level. As
a result, the Mastery student learns new tasks better under
group instruction. That is, under Mastery Learning time
on-task and rates of learning are at high levels, and proc­
essing behaviors are very effective"
"As the student’s
achievement reaches higher levels, it depends less on the
student's aptitude or intelligence. Finally, the Mastery
student's interests, attitudes, and self-concepts in regard
to learning become more and more positive.[¬e]"

ing instruction. Observers scanned the classroom at the
beginning, middle, and towards the end of an instructional
period, focussing on each child for about 5 seconds and then
rating whether that child was on-task or off-task. After
completing one scan, the observer paused and began another.
Using this process, during a single instructional period a
number of observations were made of each learner. Details
of the training of the observers will be given in the Design
section (pp. 86-88). ."
"Instructional Processing
Behaviors
During the learning activities, students' behaviors
were monitored both by self-report and by observation. On
the Components Checklist, adapted from Hecht's (1977)
"Activities Checklist", students reported the following:
(1) whether they understood the instructional cues; (2)
whether they participated frequently in the learning activi­
ties; (3) whether they were rewarded during their learning;
(4) whether they received adequate feedback and correction.[¬e]"

Page 69:
[¬s]"The content validity of these instruments was assessed
by having two judges (familiar with our definition of
instructional quality) rate whether the items or observation
categories were consistent with tour definition. Only those
items and observation categories which, according to both
judges, fit the definition of instructional quaility were
included on these instruments.[¬e]"

Page 72:
[¬s]"This research monitored three dimensions of students’
affect regarding probability: interests, attitudes, and
self-concepts. We estimated students' interests in prob­
ability from their desire to learn more about it. We esti­
mated students' attitudes toward probability by how highly
it was valued in comparison with other subjects."
"We esti­
mated students' self-concepts as learners of probability by
how highly they rated their performance in probability. The
affective instruments were described in detail in the sec­
tion "Generalized and Specific Affective Entry Characteris­
tics" (pp. 55-56). Affect was measured before instruction
began, at the beginning of each instructional task, and
after the students were informed of their final achievement.[¬e]"

Page 69:
[¬s]"This research examined how the quality of the instruc­
tion affected students' cognitive and affective learning.
Students' cognitive and affective development was monitored
for three different purposes. First, assessments were made
during the experiment to reveal the different courses of
learning under the different instructional conditions. Sec­
ond, assessment was made at the end of the instruction to
reveal the overall effects of the different instructional
conditions. And finally, assessment was made a short time
after the posttest to reveal the degree of retention under
the different instructional conditions[¬e]"

Page 70:
[¬s]"Lower mental processes were estimated from the students'
performance on test items at the Knowledge or Comprehension
levels of the Taxonomy. A Knowledge item required the stu­
dent to identify a term, fact, rule, or principle, or to use
these elements to solve problems similar to ones encountered
during the instruction. A Comprehension item required the
student to translate information from verbal to quantitative
form."
"Higher mental processes were estimated from the stu­
dents' performance on items at the Application or Analysis
levels of the Taxonomy. An Application item required the
student to use the relevant terms, facts, rules, or princi­
ples to solve a problem which was different from the ones
encountered during instructon. An Analysis item required
the student to determine what additional information beyond
what was given was necessary to develop a solution to a
problem.[¬e]"

[¬s]"Formative tests were constructed according to proce­

mental processes were expected of the students. Items for
the formative tests were chosen from the most important ele­
ments in the table of specification."
"The validity of the items was established in two steps.
First, two judges rated whether each item appropriately rep­
resented the content of the instructional unit. Next, the
judges rated, on the basis of the content and objectives of
the instructional unit, whether the item was a lower or
higher mental process item. An item was included on a for­
mative test for a given unit only if both judges agreed on
the cognitive level of the item, and that the item appropri­
ately represented the content of the instructional unit."
"A second pool of items was developed on the most impor­

[¬s]"The conceptual framework for this research was largely

References.Title: Students’ potential for learning contrasted under tutorial and group approaches to instruction.
References.Abstract: One reason for chronically low achievement is that, under conventional instruction, the teacher's time and attention are so divided among a group of students that the specific needs of each student can not be met. Under these conditions, students' learning is so full of errors that their achievement is far below their potential. Our thesis was that students' potential for learning will be developed to very high levels when instruction is fully adapted to each student's specific needs. To explore this idea, we contrasted students' cognitive and affective learning under tutoring, Mastery Learning, and conventional group instruction. Approximately 260 fourth and fifth graders participated in the three replications of this study. In each replication, students were randomly assigned to learn probability under one of the three instructional arrangements. Tutors were undergraduate education students in pre-professional training. The Mastery and the conventional conditions were managed by the students' regular mathematics teachers. Students' cognitive and affective characteristics were very similar at the beginning of instruction. By the end of three weeks, dramatic differences had emerged. The final achievement of the average tutored student was at a level above approximately 95 percent of the control students. The final achievement of the average Mastery student was at a level above approximately 85 percent of the control students. In addition, the high levels of final achievement were retained at high levels under tutoring and Mastery Learning. These differences held for both lower and higher mental processes, as defined by the Taxonomy of Educational Objectives. What is especially noteworthy, under tutoring and Mastery Learning low aptitude students achieved at higher levels than students of high aptitude who received conventional instruction. These findings have many implications for schooling. Perhaps the most important implication is that the student's potential for learning can not be accurately predicted from the student's home environment, from tests of the student's aptitude, or even from the student's prior achievement under conventional instruction. The student's full potential for learning can properly be estimated only when the student is learning under the most effective instructional conditions that can be devised.
References.Comments: This study provides results for 2 different grades (grade 4 & 5) and 3 different sites (grade 4 site 1, grade 5 site 1 & grade 5 site 2), three different groups (tutoring, mastery, conventional) and different sections of the tests used. Please compare the mastery learning vs. the conventional group on Site 2, Grade 5 focusing on FT1A, FT2A and FT3A vs post-test.
References.QuickCitation: Burke Arthur Joseph (1983) Students’ potential for learning contrasted under tutorial and group approaches to instruction.. , .

References.Title: The effects of a mastery learning strategy on achievement.
References.Abstract: Bloom has argued that most students, not just a few, should be able to do top quality school work if given appropriate instruction. Mastery learning, which includes frequent diagnostic testing followed by remedial instruction, has been proposed as an effective strategy for increasing pupil achievement. In this study, teachers used a mastery learning strategy with elementary school students in a geometry unit. An analysis of the data indicated that low mathematics aptitude fourth graders taught using a mastery strategy achieved at as high a level as high aptitude fifth graders taught in a more conventional manner.

References.Title: The effects of marked changes in student achievement pattern on the students, their teachers, and their parents: The Chilean case
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to investigate some of the major effects of a national school program in which a large-scale mastery strategy was successfully implemented. Some of the effects studied were: (1) the changes in the students' pattern of achievement, (2) the changes in the students' school-related affect, (3) the changes in teachers' view of students and of their role as teachers, and (4) the changes in parents' academic and occupational expectations for their children. The major thesis underlying the study is that improved levels of student achievement (within a class, school, or sample of the national school system) provided by an effective method of group instruction, will have a direct and positive influence on the students' school-related affect, on the teachers' view of their students and of themselves as teachers, and on parents' expectations for their children. An important factor in the study was the length of time students participated in a mastery school setting. Three samples of students comparable in selected background characteristics were studied. One sample had mastery learning instruction for three years. A second sample had mastery instruction for only a single year. The third sample had no mastery instruction. Spanish and mathematics achievement tests measured student achievement at the third, sixth, and eighth grade levels. A set of questionnaire scales measured the dependent variables relating to the affective outcomes of students, teachers, and parents. The results of the study indicate that the achievement students attain is strongly determined by the learning conditions provided in school. The average three-year mastery student was above 80 percent of the students in the conventional groups. The average one-year mastery student was above 70 percent of the students under conventional instruction. The patterns of students' school-related affect, teachers' view of students and of their role as teachers, and parents' expectations for their children were very similar to the pattern of student achievement. This suggests that increased levels of student achievement have a direct and positive effect on the affective outcomes of students, teachers, and parents.

Outcomes.Title: ACS-NSTA Cooperative Examination
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: This test was prepared by a committee of over forty active high school chemistry teachers. The instrument consists of two parts of forty multiple-choice questions each, requiring eighty minutes for the total test. The content and construct validity of the examination are expected to be high since (1) it was designed by a large number of active chemistry teachers from all segments of the United States, and (2) the objectives of the course under study were the same as those of the examination.

References.Title: The design and evaluation of an individualized, contract-directed high school chemistry course
References.Abstract:
A posttest-only, control group design was chosen for this study with random assignment of subjects. The individualized, contract-directed high school chemistry, course was characterized by the following: individual and small group activities, student self-pacing, which included teacher indicated minimum acceptable requirements, unit behavioral objectives citing multiple references, PACE learning packets for each unit that directed student day-to-day activities, PACE unit pretests, tape-recorded and printed unit summaries that assisted the student with content Integration, audio-visual experiment previews, student tutoring and team learning, topic-related seminars, lectures and demonstrations presented upon student request, investigator-designed supplementary materials for teacher-directed remedial action, topic-related full-length films and film loops, a quantity/quality grading system, and an underlying mastery learning philosophy. Standardized and unbiased administrative procedures were used to assign forty-four students to second period chemistry classes and forty-six students to third period classes. 
The significant treatment effect demonstrated on the Semester Two Examination favored the control groups' students over the experimental groups' students. The significant treatment and academic ability interaction demonstrated on the Tennessee Self-Concept Scale favored the experimental middle academic ability groups' students over the control groups' middle academic ability students. The significant treatment and academic ability interaction demonstrated on the Semester One Examination favored the middle academic ability control groups' students over the experimental groups' middle academic ability students.

References.Title: An investigation of the effectiveness of certain scheduling procedures on mathematical achievement of junior high school pupils.
References.Abstract: This investigation compared the relative effectiveness of three plans of junior high school organization on measurements of educational development and attitude using as criterion measures the grade level equivalent scores from the Modern Math Understanding Tests and weighted raw scores from the Minnesota Attitude Inventory Scale.  The Olson school day consisted of sixteen time modules of twenty-five minutes each. Students' and teachers' schedules cycled or repeated weekly. Group sixes, modes of instruction, and allocation of spaces varied considerably from the traditional format with an underlying mastery approach. The traditional Portland school day consisted of six time periods of fifty-five minutes each. Students' and teachers' schedules were constant day to day. The mathematics periods were for the most part for independent study or small group presentations. There was no difference in mean achievement, as measured by the Modern Math Understanding Test, between students taught under the modular plan and students taught under the traditional plan.  The mean score of the modular group exceeded that of the traditional group only in the high ability level and that by only one month. For the middle and low ability groups, the traditional group scored higher by five and one month, respectively.

[¬s]"Independent and Individual Study
Independent and individual study instruction in which the
students engage in activities independent of other students and
for the most part independent of immediate teacher direction is
revolutionary in the new design. Some of the learning activities
which are pursued independently are reading, writing, drill,
research, student-teacher conferences, memorisation, teaching
machine programs, speed reading, and other automatic instructional
devices. The purposes of this type of instruction are: (1) to
promote independent work, (2) to provide opportunity for study
under optimum conditions, (3) to provide opportunity for the study
of topics beyond the regular curriculum, and (4) to permit maximum
use of instructional resources.[¬e]"

References.Title: An investigation of the effectiveness of certain scheduling procedures on mathematical achievement of junior high school pupils.
References.Abstract: This investigation compared the relative effectiveness of three plans of junior high school organization on measurements of educational development and attitude using as criterion measures the grade level equivalent scores from the Modern Math Understanding Tests and weighted raw scores from the Minnesota Attitude Inventory Scale.  The Olson school day consisted of sixteen time modules of twenty-five minutes each. Students' and teachers' schedules cycled or repeated weekly. Group sixes, modes of instruction, and allocation of spaces varied considerably from the traditional format with an underlying mastery approach. The traditional Portland school day consisted of six time periods of fifty-five minutes each. Students' and teachers' schedules were constant day to day. The mathematics periods were for the most part for independent study or small group presentations. There was no difference in mean achievement, as measured by the Modern Math Understanding Test, between students taught under the modular plan and students taught under the traditional plan.  The mean score of the modular group exceeded that of the traditional group only in the high ability level and that by only one month. For the middle and low ability groups, the traditional group scored higher by five and one month, respectively.
References.Comments: MDE: This study includes 3 arms. Please code for modular group (intervention) vs Traditional (control). ESDE: Compare modular group (intervention) versus Traditional (control). Use the unweighted means and SDs from Table 13 for the SRA Modern Math Understanding test. You will need to combine the SDs for M & F using the Ns for the respective cells from Table 5 on p 164. There is a spreadsheet on Slack which supports combining means and SDs. This will allow a post-test only comparison. Any questions please check with Steve.Original file is 57MB

References.Title: An evaluative study of the northwest junior high school individualised mathematics program
References.Abstract:
This study was designed to compare the effectiveness of a individualized mastery instructional program with a traditional classroom instructional program in mathematics at Northwest Junior High School in Salt Lake City. This study was conducted in order to learn if individualized
instruction or traditional classroom instruction in selected mathematics subject matter would yield significant difference as measured by standardized tests. Also, it was desired to learn if individualized instruction and materials would yield significant difference in workstudy skills when compared to traditional instruction by standardized tests. The study was conducted to also learn if there would be significant difference on standardized tests in computational achievement between the fifteen subjects with lowest intelligence quotient receiving individualized instruction and the fifteen subjects with lowest intelligence quotient receiving traditional instruction. Finally, it was desired to know if there would be significant difference between subjects receiving individualized instruction compared to subjects receiving traditional instruction in the length of time needed to complete the study of selected subject matter. It was predicted that the individualized group subject would use more time. The thirty-one subjects who received traditional instruction and who are hereafter referred to as control group subjects, were randomly selected from the population which was the total enrollment of 914 at Northwest Junior High School. The thirty-one subjects who received individualized instruction and who are hereafter referred to as experimental group subjects, were individually matched to the control group subjects according to sex, age, intelligence quotient, and mathematics achievement. At the beginning of the study, eighth grade students were given the Stanford Achievement, Arithmetic Computation sub-test. Form X,and the Iowa Test of Basic Skills, Test W, Form 1. The Stanford Test scores were used to help identify the experimental group subjects and as a pre-test to determine a mathematics achievement score. The Iowa Test of Basic Skills was used to determine a pre-test score in work-study skills. When the pre-testing was complete, the control group subjects received traditional instruction in the topics of decimal fractions, percent and ratio and proportion. Hie experimental group subjects first received a prescription to remove any subject matter deficiencies and then received individualized instruction in the same topics as the control group subjects. Control group subjects were given post-tests at the same time. Experimental group subjects were given post-tests when the subject and the instructor decided that the subject was prepared to be tested. Control group subjects wrote individual comments comparing their opinions of individualized instruction, which they had experienced as seventh graders, and traditional instruction. The pre-test scores were analyzed and t-tests were used to determine whether or not there were significant differences in the achievement of control group subjects and experimental group subjects before the treatment. The t-tests were used to determine if significance existed from the pre-test to the post-test scores. The tests were run on the post-test scores to determine if significance existed after instruction. An analysis of the findings showed that there was significant difference in favor of the control group, between control and experimental subjects in mathematics achievement. There was no significant difference in work-study skills achievement between control group subjects and experimental group subjects. There was no significant difference in mathematics achievement between the fifteen subjects with lowest intelligence quotient in the control group and the fifteen subjects with lowest intelligence quotient in the experimental group. There was significant difference in the amount of time needed to complete the study. The significance favored the control group subjects who used less time than the mean time of experimental group subjects.

References.Title: Three types of programmed learning and the conventional teaching of the nuclear chemistry portion of a high school chemistry course.
References.Abstract: The problem investigated in the study was a comparison of the learning and retention of the facts and principles of nuclear chemistry in the high school chemistry course using three forms of programed materials and the conventional lecture-demonstration method of teaching. The three forms of programed materials were linear short-step, long-step linear, and branched programs. A list of operational objectives and an outline of content objectives both were prepared prior to the preparation of the short-step program. The program was drafted and initially tested with a full high school chemistry class. In further development and revision, segments of the program were presented to several high school students and two experienced high school teachers. A final testing of the program was accomplished by using it with a full high school class. The branched form of the program was prepared from the basic form by identifying key items and rearranging the basic program to allow students who answered the key items correctly to skip over practice and review frames. The longstep form of the program was prepared by deleting repeating, practice and review frames. A multiple choice, forty-four item achievement test in nuclear chemistry was constructed. Preliminary evaluations in three high schools with intact classes were each followed by a revision to produce a more reliable instrument. The basic test was used as both pre-test and retention test for / 2 the study. The post-test was an alternative form of the basic test. Validation of the test instrument and the programs was carried on by submitting them to a jury of five experienced high school teachers. Students who participated in the four study treatments were from two high schools in the same school district. The approximately 150 students initially in each group were reduced to twenty-six students per group when matched across groups on total number of science courses and total number of mathematics courses taken, measured intelligence and reading scores. During the study, experimental programs were administered by the usual classroom teachers of chemistry. The time for classroom consideration of nuclear chemistry was seven class days. The pre-test was administered immediately before the study of nuclear chemistry was initiated. The post-test was given the class period following completion of the study of nuclear chemistry and the retention test was given two months after the study was completed. All groups learned a significant amount during their study of nuclear chemistry. Statistical comparison of pretest post-test gain using an analysis of covariance showed that the groups using programs, considered as a unit, gained significantly more than the control group. Between groups comparisons using a t-test on gain means showed that only the pre-test post-test gain by the group using the branched form of the program was significantly greater than the gain 3 of the control group. On the post-test of achievement, the variance of the group using the branched form of the program was significantly smaller than that of the control group. The correlation of measured intelligence and achievement was significantly smaller for the group using the long-step program than the control group. Statistical comparison of retention test scores using an analysis of covariance showed that the control group had a significantly greater retention of the facts and principles of nuclear chemistry when compared to all groups using programed materials. The following conclusions could be made regarding the study: 1. Students using a branched form of a program to study nuclear chemistry achieved significantly more than those using the conventional lecture-demonstration method. Students using a long-step form of the program learned more than the control but the difference in gain means was not significant. 2. Students studying nuclear chemistry using the conventional lecture-demonstration method retained significantly more than those using the three forms of programed materials. 3. Individual differences were cared for at least in part as students using the branched form of the program had a smaller variance on the final test of achievement than those in the control group. Also, the correlation between achievement and measured intelligence was significantly smaller for the group using the long-step program than for the control.
References.Comments: This study has 4 groups: control, short step linear, long step linear and branched treatment. Please code the control vs. short step.
References.QuickCitation: Darnowski Vincent S (1968) Three types of programmed learning and the conventional teaching of the nuclear chemistry portion of a high school chemistry course.. , New York University.

[¬s]"Analysis of covariance (ANCOVA) methods were used to test the effects of
the interventions on their proximal targets within gender. Boys and girls are
treated separately because the temporal regression of spring values on fall values
differs significantly in slope for almost all the key variables. Pooling the genders
sharply violates the assumptions of analysis of covariance. The interventions
were compared separately to each of their controls because the control groups
were not considered to be poolable. The differences between the control groups,
which in some cases were quite large, were not allowed to confound the compari-
son of the intervention with each control.[¬e]"

References.Title: The short-term impact of two classroom-based preventive interventions on aggressive and shy behaviors and poor achievement
References.Abstract: Two classroom-based preventive interventions were carried out on an epidemiologically defined, varied population of children in a metropolitan area in the United States. This is a report of the short-term impact and specificity of the two interventions from fall through spring of first grade. The first intervention, the Good Behavior Game, was aimed at reducing aggressive behavior and shy behavior. Aggressive behavior has been shown to be an important developmental antecedent in first grade of later delinquency and heavy drug use, particularly when coupled with shy behavior. The second intervention, Mastery Learning, was designed to improve poor reading achievement, which has been shown to be an antecedent for later depressive symptoms, as well as a correlate of aggressive and shy behaviors. Each of the two interventions had a significant and very specific impact only on its own proximal target(s). In addition to main effects, there were theoretically important variations of impacts among subgroups of children. The Good Behavior Game appeared to have a greater impact in reducing aggressive behavior among the more aggressive children. The nature of the impact of Mastery Learning differed by gender, with female high achievers benefiting more from the intervention than female low achievers, and male low achievers benefiting more than male high achievers. Developmental epidemiologically based preventive trials provide a powerful means of addressing questions about etiology and development, particularly around the issue of the malleability of developmental processes. Important questions that future work could test are whether achievement is improved by improving aggressive or shy behaviors and whether aggressive or shy behaviors are improved by improving achievement. Such investigation would inform our understanding of their etiology. © 1993.
References.Comments: This study has 2 interventions, two control groups (internal & external) and results are presented for boys and girls seperatly. Please code the mastery learning (ML) which has academic outcomes. Also code ML against internal control for boys.

Critical aspects of the training program included agroup-based approach to mastery, amore flexible corrective process, and material support. The develop- ment of amore group-paced approach to mastery meant that students did not proceed to the next learning unit until the majority (80% achieving 80-85% of objectives) of students had fulfilled the learning objectives of the previous unit. The systematic provision and use of correctives constitutes another key to the effectiveness of ML. Corrective instruction, by its very nature, must be targeted toward particular learners and particular learning difficulties. The corrective process developed for this intervention was flexible in terms of time, grouping strategy, and variety of correctives. A systematic linking of objectives, test items, error prescriptions, and correctives was developed and reinforced through an instructional management model. Further details about the training are con- tained in The Mastery Learning Manual (Dolan, Ford, Newton, & Kellam, 1989). [¬e]"

References.Title: The short-term impact of two classroom-based preventive interventions on aggressive and shy behaviors and poor achievement
References.Abstract: Two classroom-based preventive interventions were carried out on an epidemiologically defined, varied population of children in a metropolitan area in the United States. This is a report of the short-term impact and specificity of the two interventions from fall through spring of first grade. The first intervention, the Good Behavior Game, was aimed at reducing aggressive behavior and shy behavior. Aggressive behavior has been shown to be an important developmental antecedent in first grade of later delinquency and heavy drug use, particularly when coupled with shy behavior. The second intervention, Mastery Learning, was designed to improve poor reading achievement, which has been shown to be an antecedent for later depressive symptoms, as well as a correlate of aggressive and shy behaviors. Each of the two interventions had a significant and very specific impact only on its own proximal target(s). In addition to main effects, there were theoretically important variations of impacts among subgroups of children. The Good Behavior Game appeared to have a greater impact in reducing aggressive behavior among the more aggressive children. The nature of the impact of Mastery Learning differed by gender, with female high achievers benefiting more from the intervention than female low achievers, and male low achievers benefiting more than male high achievers. Developmental epidemiologically based preventive trials provide a powerful means of addressing questions about etiology and development, particularly around the issue of the malleability of developmental processes. Important questions that future work could test are whether achievement is improved by improving aggressive or shy behaviors and whether aggressive or shy behaviors are improved by improving achievement. Such investigation would inform our understanding of their etiology. © 1993.
References.Comments: This study has 2 interventions, two control groups (internal & external) and results are presented for boys and girls seperatly. Please code the mastery learning (ML) which has academic outcomes. Also code ML against external control for boys.

[¬s]"SHORT-TERM IMPACT OFPREVENTIVE INTERVENTIONS 325 variety of corrective methods until mastery was reached; presentation of mastery standards for each instructional unit; immediate feedback to students; and clear and updated records of student progress. Critical aspects of the training program included agroup-based approach to mastery, amore flexible corrective process, and material support. The develop- ment of amore group-paced approach to mastery meant that students did not proceed to the next learning unit until the majority (80% achieving 80-85% of objectives) of students had fulfilled the learning objectives of the previous unit. The systematic provision and use of correctives constitutes another key to the effectiveness of ML. Corrective instruction, by its very nature, must be targeted toward particular learners and particular learning difficulties. The corrective process developed for this intervention was flexible in terms of time, grouping strategy, and variety of correctives. A systematic linking of objectives, test items, error prescriptions, and correctives was developed and reinforced through an instructional management model. Further details about the training are con- tained in The Mastery Learning Manual (Dolan, Ford, Newton, & Kellam, 1989).[¬e]"

References.Title: A comparative study of the effects on achievement and changes in attitude of senior high school students enrolled in first year algebra under two different teaching approaches
References.Abstract:
All students enrolled in first year algebra at Cleveland Heights High School took part In the study.  Each class was to contain between twenty and twenty-five students. Each of the six classes was scheduled at a different time of the school day. All students were randomly assigned to classes by computer, with the exception of those who transferred to the school from other schools. Three pretests were administered to each of six different classes. These classes included a control and experimental class of three different teachers. The pretests Included the Cooperative Arithmetic Test, the Cooperative Structure of the Number System, and the Attitude Toward Mathematics Scale. The classes were taught using the group-orlented approach in the control classes and an individualized approach with a 70% mastery criterion in the experimental classes. All classes used the same textbook. A t test was employed on the means of the losses in raw scores from the arithmetic pretest to the algebra posttest and on the means of the gains in raw scores from the Structure of the Number System pretest to the algebra
posttest. The hypothesis concerning achievement could not be rejected with respect to the groups of Teacher A and C. However, the results of the two t tests with respect to the groups of Teacher B were inconsistent. In one case a significant difference was found while no significant difference was found in the other. A t test was also used on the means of gains in raw scores from the attitude pretest to the attitude posttest. No significant differences could be found. Therefore, the hypothesis concerning attitudes could not be rejected.
References.Comments: There are 2 groups and 3 different teachers (A, B, C). Results are presented comparing experimental & control group  by each teacher. Please code Teacher A comparing exp. & control.CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is a scanned file and too large to upload. Please contact the team if you would like access to this.

References.Title: A comparative study of the effects on achievement and changes in attitude of senior high school students enrolled in first year algebra under two different teaching approaches
References.Abstract: All students enrolled in first year algebra at Cleveland Heights High School took part In the study. Each class was to contain between twenty and twenty-five students. Each of the six classes was scheduled at a different time of the school day. All students were randomly assigned to classes by computer, with the exception of those who transferred to the school from other schools. Three pretests were administered to each of six different classes. These classes included a control and experimental class of three different teachers. The pretests Included the Cooperative Arithmetic Test, the Cooperative Structure of the Number System, and the Attitude Toward Mathematics Scale. The classes were taught using the group-orlented approach in the control classes and an individualized approach with a 70% mastery criterion in the experimental classes. All classes used the same textbook. A t test was employed on the means of the losses in raw scores from the arithmetic pretest to the algebra posttest and on the means of the gains in raw scores from the Structure of the Number System pretest to the algebra posttest. The hypothesis concerning achievement could not be rejected with respect to the groups of Teacher A and C. However, the results of the two t tests with respect to the groups of Teacher B were inconsistent. In one case a significant difference was found while no significant difference was found in the other. A t test was also used on the means of gains in raw scores from the attitude pretest to the attitude posttest. No significant differences could be found. Therefore, the hypothesis concerning attitudes could not be rejected.
References.Comments: There are 2 groups and 3 different teachers (A, B, C). Results are presented comparing experimental & control group by each teacher. Please code Teacher B comparing exp. & control.CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is a scanned file and too large to upload. Please contact the team if you would like access to this.

The average level of fonnal parental education is approximately 14 years. Approximately 70 percent of the parents are members of the professional employment conmunity. There are a total of 1,067 students enrolled in the school. Of these students approximately 82 percent are Anglo-American and approxi- 111ately 18 percent are Negro. There were only 11 Mexican-American stu- dents enrolled in the school during the 1974-75 school year. Almost all of the Negro students in the school are bused in."

now live in the original school district.
The average educational[¬e]"

significantly since 1969. The ethnic breakdown is now 53 percent Negro,

[¬s]"The materials used in this study were developed by the researcher.
The pupil text, Transportation and the Environment, was published by the
Georgraphy Curriculum Project, University of Georgia[¬e]"

Page 13:
[¬s]"The treatment variable in this study consisted of two teaching
strategies. One was a mastery learning strategy and one was a non-
mastery strategy.[¬e]"

Page 14:
[¬s]"A total of 17 classe 'S was obtained in the two schools. Due to the
practical considerations involved in the selection process, the classes
represented an available pool of students rather than a random sample.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"Transportation and the Environment is a systematic,
cognitively based, and conceptually oriented unit. Certain key concepts[¬e]"

Page 4:
[¬s]"are identified at the beginning of each chapter. The concepts are se-
quenced so that later chapters build upon concepts discussed in previous
chapters. The major objective of the unit is to help students obtain
basic data on some of the organizing concepts of transportation geography.
Students should then be able to apply this data base to the study of
various relationships of transportation and the envirorvnent."
"Transportation and the Environment looks at American transportation
from three perspectives--(1) historical development (chapters 1-6), (2)
effect upon environment (chapters 7-9) and (3) alternatives to current
practices (chapters 10-13). The specific contents of the chapters are
shown in Table 3.1.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"Any treatment of trans- portation within a spatial/environmental context is usually conducted through the avenue of current events. This approach tends to be sporadic and incomplete."
"A major purpose of the unit Trans-
portation and the Environment is to help fill this void. By utilizing
this important topic as a vehicle, students are able to study in a more
complete and systematic fashion some of the societal and environmental
consequences of transportation.[¬e]"

Page 4:
[¬s]"The major objective of the unit is to help students obtain

Page 21:
[¬s]"The researcher met with the four participating teachers during two
one-hour sessions prior to beginning the experimental study. The teach-
ers had previously received copies of Transportation and the Environment.
The purpose of the meetings was to thoroughly acquaint the teachers with
all of the procedures and materials used in the study.
The first orientation meeting centered around the mastery and non-
mastery treatments. The teachers were told that they would be assigned
to aminister only one treatment. The researcher provided the teachers
with copies of the suggested procedures for the study. After reading
the procedures, the teachers suggested some changes to accomnodate the
poor readers. Since none of the changes altered the primary focus of
the treatments, they were incorporated into the study. The changes are
discussed in the next section.
The second orientation meeting was concerned with the instructional
materials used in the study. By the time of this meeting, the teacher
had had time to review the text, review sheets, and formative tests.
The researcher went over these materi'als with the teachers and answered
questions relating to the materials. The remainder of the meeting in-
volved the question of introducing the unit of study to the students.[¬e]"

converted to a grade level, this score falls on the borderline between a
grade seven and a grade eight reading level. However, because of the
technical vocabulary an upper eighth or ninth grade reading level is
probably a more accurate estimate of actual reading level.[¬e]"

period lasting from March 10, 1975 to April 22, 1975.[¬e]"

Page 24:
[¬s]"The original procedures called for the students to
read the lessons in the text independently. However, due to the large
number of poor readers and non-readers in the experimental st udy, this
was abandoned. Instead, the teachers recorded the lessons in the text[¬e]"

Page 25:
[¬s]"on audio tapes. The tapes were played in class and the students fol-

References.Title: Mastery Learning: The Relationship of Mastery Procedures and Aptitude to the Achievement and Retention of Transportation-Environmental Concepts by Seventh Grade Students.
References.Institution: University Microfilms, P.O. Box 1764, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48106 (Order No. 76-6402, microfilm $10.00, xerography $20.00)
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to compare the effects of two treatment variables, mastery and aptitude, on two outcome variables, achievement and retention, as measured by researcher-constructed tests. Seventeen classes of seventh-grade geography students were taught an instructor-developed geography unit with either mastery or nonmastery procedures. The mastery procedures contained corrective feedback components which were omitted for the nonmastery classes. The results indicated that there were no significant differences in either achievement or retention between mastery and nonmastery classes. Aptitude, as measured by a vocabulary test, correlated highly with unit achievement and retention regardless of the instruction strategy used. Therefore, verbal capability appears to be the overriding determinant of achievement or retention. Since mastery procedures normally require more time than nonmastery procedures and do not produce higher achievement levels, their use is questionable. (Author/DE)

References.Title: An analysis of student outcomes utilizing two approaches to teaching BSCS biology.
References.Abstract: Eighth grade students using the Biological Sciences Curriculum Study (BSCS) Blue Version materials in a typical classroom setting with large group instruction were compared with students in an "individualized" class who were allowed to work through similar materials at their own rates. Both classes were initially comparable with respect to their scores on the "Iowa Test of Basic Skills". Students in the individualized class performed significantly better on the "BSCS Comprehensive Final Examination", the "Test On Understanding Science", the "Facts About Science" test, the "Watson-Glaser Critical Thinking Appraisal"; had a better attitude toward science (Prouse Subject Preference Survey); and rated the teacher significantly higher on the "Performance Scale for High School Biology Teachers" than did students in the large groups approach. There were no significant differences on the "BSCS Achievement Tests" and the "Nelson Biology Test". (Author/AL)
References.Comments: Please focus in coding results for total biology and total achievement tests not subtests.

References.Title: A study of the effect of different approaches to the teaching of vocabulary on reading achievement and vocabulary development at the fifth grade level.
References.Abstract: The basic design of this experiment was the nonequivalent control group design. There were three fifth grade classes in the Experimental I treatment, three in the Experimental II treatment and three in the control treatment. These nine classes were randomly selected from fourteen fifth grade classes in six schools and randomly assigned to treatment groups. The subjects in this study were children of nine fifth grade classes from six schools in the Cortland Public School System, Cortland, New York. Class size varied from 19 to 30 students. At the time of pretesting there were 209 children included in the experiment. Due to attrition, this sample dwindled to 185 when the final data were collected. Therefore, in this study only the pre and posttest scores of the final 185 subjects were used in the data analysis.  Experimental I - (IVD) - the children in this group followed the treatment labeled Individual Vocabulary Development (IVD). The children worked on their vocabulary exercises individually with assistance from the teacher if needed to achieve mastery. Experimental II - (PGIVD) - the children in this group followed the treatment labeled Peer Group Interaction Vocabulary Development (PGIVD). These children worked on their self-directing and self-correcting vocabulary exercises in groups of twos, threes, or fours formed within the confines of the three vocabulary levels to achieve mastery. Control Treatment - (RCPVD) - The children in this group followed the regular classroom procedure for Vocabulary development, and is therefore labeled RCPVD. The entire Cortland School System uses the Lippincott Readers as the main basal series.  Reading achievement was measured by the Gates MacGinitie Reading Test, Survey D, Form-M administered as a pretest. Growth in reading achievement was measured by Form 2-M of the same instrument, administered as a posttest. There were no significant differences among any of the three treatment groups in vocabulary, comprehension or total reading posttest means on the Gates-McGinitie Reading Test at the end of the experiment.

Outcomes.Title: MacGinitie reading total - ML
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: MacGinitie reading achievement: Total for vocabulary + comprehension – mastery Learning (treatment IVD vs control RCPVD)

References.Title: A study of the effect of different approaches to the teaching of vocabulary on reading achievement and vocabulary development at the fifth grade level.
References.Abstract: The basic design of this experiment was the nonequivalent control group design. There were three fifth grade classes in the Experimental I treatment, three in the Experimental II treatment and three in the control treatment. These nine classes were randomly selected from fourteen fifth grade classes in six schools and randomly assigned to treatment groups. The subjects in this study were children of nine fifth grade classes from six schools in the Cortland Public School System, Cortland, New York. Class size varied from 19 to 30 students. At the time of pretesting there were 209 children included in the experiment. Due to attrition, this sample dwindled to 185 when the final data were collected. Therefore, in this study only the pre and posttest scores of the final 185 subjects were used in the data analysis. Experimental I - (IVD) - the children in this group followed the treatment labeled Individual Vocabulary Development (IVD). The children worked on their vocabulary exercises individually with assistance from the teacher if needed to achieve mastery. Experimental II - (PGIVD) - the children in this group followed the treatment labeled Peer Group Interaction Vocabulary Development (PGIVD). These children worked on their self-directing and self-correcting vocabulary exercises in groups of twos, threes, or fours formed within the confines of the three vocabulary levels to achieve mastery. Control Treatment - (RCPVD) - The children in this group followed the regular classroom procedure for Vocabulary development, and is therefore labeled RCPVD. The entire Cortland School System uses the Lippincott Readers as the main basal series. Reading achievement was measured by the Gates MacGinitie Reading Test, Survey D, Form-M administered as a pretest. Growth in reading achievement was measured by Form 2-M of the same instrument, administered as a posttest. There were no significant differences among any of the three treatment groups in vocabulary, comprehension or total reading posttest means on the Gates-McGinitie Reading Test at the end of the experiment.
References.Comments: CODERS: Please use OCR version for highlighting. The original pdf is a scanned file and too large to upload. Please contact the team if you would like access to this. ESDE: Coders this study has 3 groups; IND, PGIVD & RCPVD. For study 2 please focus in coding IND vs. RCPVD.
References.QuickCitation: Halliwell D D (1975) A study of the effect of different approaches to the teaching of vocabulary on reading achievement and vocabulary development at the fifth grade level.. Dissertation Abstracts International 35(11-A), 7030-7030

Page 6:
[¬s]" assessed the impact of Mathematics Mastery on pupils in Year 7, after the programme had been implemented in schools for one year.[¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]"A clustered randomised controlled trial (RCT) has been used, with random allocation at the school level. The Mathematics Mastery programme involves a change to the maths curriculum within schools – therefore randomisation at either the pupil or class level was inappropriate.[¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]"A clustered randomised controlled trial (RCT) has been used, with random allocation at the school level. [¬e]"

Page 15:
[¬s]"All aspects of the randomisation were conducted by the independent evaluation team. Schools were ranked by the percentage of children who achieved A* – C in GCSE English and Maths, using the most recent data available at the time of randomisation (this was the 2011/2012 academic year). Schools were then divided into pairs, and a random number generated for each using Excel. The school with the higher random number within each pair was assigned to intervention, and the school with the lower number within each pair to control.[¬e]"

Page 22:
[¬s]"After excluding children with missing post-test data, pupil sample sizes fell to 3,251 in the intervention group (81% of the original allocation) and 2,687 in the control group (72% of the original allocation). These 5,938 children form the analysis sample.[¬e]"

Page 12:
[¬s]"The programme aims to build fluency and understanding of underlying mathematical concepts through practice and consolidation. For example, the Mathematics Mastery programme of study for Year 7 includes 25 hours of work on fractions, including multiplication and division of fractions. One task that is offered during this topic is shown here. Pupils are asked to find which of the following expressions are equal to one-quarter. a) 1/3 × 3/4 b) 1/8 × 1/2 c) 13/22 × 11/26 d) 6/7 × 11/26 e) 4/3 × 3/16 f) 15/28 × 7/15 g) 8/9 × 9/32 h) 9/10 × 5/18 i) 1/2 × 1/2 j) 5/3 × 3/20 k) 9/8 × 2/3 l) 1/4× 1 m) 1/2× 1/4 × 2 n) 1/2 × 1/2 ×4 o) 1/3 × 1/8 × 18/3 p) 1/3 × 1/1 This task is designed to offer pupils the practice they need to develop fluency in multiplying fractions, while also encouraging them to engage conceptually with both the relative size of fractions and the effect of multiplication. For example: Why is expression (a) equal to one-quarter? What models or diagrams might you use to convince someone of this? Expression (e) is also equal to one-quarter. Compare (a) and (e). What is the same and what is different? If we already know that (a) is equal to one-quarter, how could we quickly know that (e) is also equal to one-quarter? How do you know that expression (l) is equal to one-quarter? How can you use the formal method for multiplying fractions to calculate the product? How can you know that expression (p) is not equal to one-quarter without calculating? Higher-attaining pupils, who have completed the full set of practice exercises and engaged with the above considerations, would not be ‘extended’ by moving on to division of fractions, or to a new topic. Instead, they are asked when the following are equal to one-quarter, and why. q) a/2 × 1/2a r) 1/4 × b/c s) d/4 × e/d This requires pupils to generalise from their conceptual understanding of the fraction products.[¬e]"

Page 8:
[¬s]"The Mathematics Mastery programme is a whole-school approach to teaching mathematics that aims to raise attainment for all pupils and close the attainment gap between pupils from low income families and their peers. The programme aims to deepen pupils’ conceptual understanding of key mathematical concepts. Compared to traditional curricula, fewer topics are covered in more depth and greater emphasis is placed on problem solving and on encouraging mathematical thinking.[¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]"Training and in-school support: headteachers, maths coordinators and class teachers receive 1 – 2 days of launch training, two in-school development visits, three multi-school cluster workshops, and access to an online toolkit with continuous professional development (CPD) resources, assessments, and leadership frameworks.[¬e]"

Page 13:
[¬s]"The GL Assessment ‘Progress in Maths’ (PiM) 12 test (www.gl-assessment.co.uk/products/progress- maths ) was used to examine children’s skills in mathematics. This was administered using paper -and- pencil tests by class teachers within a standard maths lesson and took approximately one hour to complete."
"Primary outcome  Total raw scores obtained across the whole of the Progress in Maths test Secondary outcomes  Total raw scores on the subset of questions covered in the Mathematics Mastery curriculum 4  Total raw scores on the calculator section of the Progress in Maths test  Total raw scores on the non-calculator section of the Progress in Maths test[¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]" The majority of schools participating in the trial were from London or the South East (a significant minority were based in the Midlands). [¬e]"

Page 11:
[¬s]"eachers are supported to put the principles into day-to-day practice through high-quality mastery- aligned ‘lesson designs’[¬e]"

Page 46:
[¬s]"There is an upfront cost of £6,000 for participating in the first year of the programme. (This is an ‘at cost’ price charged by Ark to cover basic infrastructure .) Ten days of staff time is required for training: half a day for the headteacher, two and a half days for the head of maths, and one day for each maths teacher (there were on average seven maths teachers per school). To calculate the cost of headteachers’ time, we take the median point on the headteacher pay scale in England and Wales (£75,222 11 ). This is then divided by 230 (the approximate number of working days in a year) to give a headteacher day rate of £327. 12 We then inflate this figure by a fifth to allow for other costs not directly incorporated into headteachers’ salaries (e.g. employer contributions to pensions) , giving a total cost of £392. 13 Analogous calculations have been made for heads of mathematics (two and a half days training at a final day rate of £251) 14 and class teachers (a total of seven days training, one day per teacher, at a final day rate of £141). 15 Thus total training costs are therefore equal to £1,740 per school per annum. This gives a total cost per secondary school of £7,740. There were, on average, 154 pupils per secondary school (7,712 children across the 50 initially recruited schools). The per- pupil cost therefore equals £50 per annum for this first year, with the cost per pupil likely to reduce in future years.[¬e]"

ItemAttributeFullTextDetails.Text:
Page 8:
[¬s]" In Mathematics Mastery, the class spent longer than usual on each concept or procedure the first time they studied it, but they did not significantly delay the starting of new topics in the event that some pupils were still unable to achieve mastery. [¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]" It was initially developed by Ark Schools to meet its aspiration to achieve success for every pupil.[¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]"A key element of the approach is the introduction of a ‘mastery curriculum’, similar to those seen in cities that lead the international tables, such as Shanghai and Singapore (see Guskey, 2010).[¬e]"

Page 10:
[¬s]" A key element of the approach is the introduction of a ‘mastery curriculum’, similar to those seen in cities that lead the international tables, such as Shanghai and Singapore (see Guskey, 2010).[¬e]"

Page 11:
[¬s]"In addition to the ‘mastery curriculum’, other features of the approach include a systematic approach to mathematical language (see Hoyles, 1985; Lee, 1998), frequent use of objects and pictures to represent mathematical concepts (see Heddens, 1986; Sowell, 1989), and an emphasis on high expectations (see Dweck, 2006; Boaler, 2010). The approach also aims to build fluency and understanding of underlying mathematical concepts in tandem, so that pupils gain deep conceptual understanding (see Skemp, 1976; Freudenthal, 1968).[¬e]"

References.Title: Mathematics Mastery: Secondary Evaluation report
References.Abstract: The Mathematics Mastery programme is a whole-school approach to teaching mathematics that aims to raise attainment for all pupils and close the attainment gap between pupils from low income families and their peers. The programme aims to deepen pupils’ conceptual understanding of key mathematical concepts. Compared to traditional curricula, fewer topics are covered in more depth, and greater emphasis is placed on problem solving and on encouraging mathematical thinking. This evaluation assessed the impact of Mathematics Mastery on pupils in Year 7, after the programme had been implemented in schools for one year. It was intended that schools would also begin to use the programme in Year 8 in the second year of implementation, and continue until the approach was in place across the school. 44 schools from London and the South East participated in the trial, with a total sample of 5,938 pupils. Participating schools received training and resources to support the adoption of the programme, which was delivered by the education charity Ark.
References.Comments: Please note there are two documents attached. One is the secondary maths mastery trial report. The other is the overarching summary report across both primary and secondary. Please focus only on the secondary school trial for this data extraction.

References.Title: Improving Reading Comprehension: Embedding Diverse Learning Strategies within a Mastery Learning Instructional Framework.
References.ParentTitle: Paper presented at the annual meeting of the American Educational Research Association, San Francisco. (ERIC Document Reproduction Service No. ED 170 698)
References.Abstract: The paper describes the theoretical background, implementation and preliminary results of the Chicago Mastery Learning/Learning Strategies reading program for upper elementary school students. Reading research and learning strategies research are pulled together to support the argument that the teaching of diverse learning strategies can improve reading comprehension and that the strategies should be embedded within the mastery learning framework. Since the purpose of this study was to develop and field test the materials, a controlled experiment was not conducted. Field test results (involving six classrooms matched on four variables related to achievement) strongly suggested that teaching learning strategies improves reading comprehension. (Author)
