[¬s]"Unit Teaching The unit teaching step of the strategy encourages each teacher to conduct instruction in his regular m.1nner. No drastic alteration of teach- ing style nor extensive training is necessary to implement the str~tegy. Since unit teaching is associated with teaching style and materials of in- struction, this step is related to Ca r ro Tl 's quality of instruction variable."
"Formative Tests and Feedback
The formative tests administered after unit instruction and the sub-
sequent feedback of student perform.1nce on these tests are related to the
Carroll variables aptitude and mo t tva t i on,
If a student has a high aptitude
for the tasks presented on the formative tests, he needs little time to master
them. The amount of time spent in the unit teaching phase might be sufficient
for many students t.o master the instructional objectives. Hence mastery
students will attain mastery level on the formative test, recognize that
they have spent sufficient time on the mathematics unit, receiVl! reinforce-
ment for time they spent in study, and thereby be motivated (willing to[¬e]"

Page 7:
[¬s]"spend time) to study the next unit. Other students, those who do not attain
mastery level on the formative test, might be made aware by their non-
mastery performance that more time needed to be spent on this mathematics
unit to attain mastery of all the instructional objectives. The non-mastery
students would have learned, however, where to best spend their time. That
is, one such student would have mastered some objectives and on these he
need spend no further time.
Ile might be willing to spend more time to study
a specific mathematics task rather than obeying an admonition to review the
entire teaching unit. Moreover, he is provided specific prescriptions for
learning those unmastered objectives."
"Alternative Materials
The formative tests uerc designed to diagnose a student's difficulties
while the alternative resources provided a prescription for remediation.
Each item of a formative test is keyed to an instructional objective and
accompanied by several suggestions of activities which, if used, could
promote mastery of the objectives. The sugecsted activities comprise the
alternative resources for a unit. The resources might include printed ma-
terial, films, tapes, educational games as well as suggested grouping for
instruction (tutorials, small group, etc.). Since the student is free to choose
among several resources for a specific objective he will probably select that
material which appeals to him most. Moreover, by providing materials not
usual to many classes, such as filmstrips or games, the alternative materials
might provide further mo t Lvn t Lon for a student to spend time on mathematics.[¬e]"

Page 8:
[¬s]"Re-test
After students are given an opportunity to us~ th~ alternative re-
sources, progress is again assessed on a re-tPst. Seeing that use of alterna-
tive materials can effect mastery may encourage further use of materials on
the present teaching unit as well as future units. Thus evidence on the
re-test that the strategy can produce mastery might encourage the student
to increase the time he spends on mathematics.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"Specification of course objectives in behavioral terms toeether with
designation of mastery level for s unnna t i vc evaluation, initial steps of the
Bloom stratcsy, provide menns of recoenizing when a student has attained
mastery. Moreover, clearly defined objectives and a pre-set mastery level
inform both the teacher and pupil of expectations for the course of instruc-[¬e]"

Page 5:
[¬s]"tion. The teacher, having course expectations clearly delineated and having
full knowledge of them, might then concentrate on innovative ways to imple-
ment the objectives, thus affecting what Carroll calls the quality of in-
struction.[¬e]"

References.Title: A strategy of mastery learning in fifth grade arithmetic
References.Abstract: The Carroll Model of school learning provides a conceptual design of variables affecting success in school learning. The Bloom mastery learning strategy proposes a sequence of steps which together encompass the variables of the Carroll Model and is, then, one implementation of this model. The present study attempted to apply the Bloom strategy in fifth grade classes in the subject of mathematics for one school year. Could this Bloom strategy be effective for a school year (nine months) in a regular curriculum content area for elementary students? Moreover, since there exists a deficit in learning among students of lower-socio-economic classes in relation to students of middle-socio-economic classes, school instruction may influence the achievement of groups of students in various ways. Would the Bloom strategy be equally effective when used in the classes of two different socio-economic communities? These two questions constituted the major focus of this study. Using the pre-test scores on the two Stanford Achievement sub-tests (Concepts and Applications) and the pre-test scores on the Mastery Criterion Test as covariates, an analysis of covariance produced no significant interaction on post-test scores between socio-economic class and treatment. It is clear that the experimental classes did not differ significantly from the control classes, nor did the Community L classes differ from the previous year's class on achievement scores. However, in Community M, the experimental classes did attain mastery of the mastery criterion in greater numbers and to a significantly higher degree than their previous year control classes. The time series study shows no increased learning rate for experimental classes of Community l-1 on the Stanford Applications sub-test, nor any increase for the Stanford Concepts sub-test. On the basis of data we conclude that the results are inconclusive with respect to the main study hypothesis.

References.Title: A comparison of learning outcomes in CBA chemistry when group and individualized instruction techniques are employed.
References.Abstract: Grade 10 students using the Chemical Bond Approach (CBA) materials in a typical classroom setting with large group instruction were compared with students in an "individualized" class using a laboratory-centered, self-paced approach. Both groups were initially comparable with respect to grade nine scores on the "Iowa Test of Educational Development". Students in the individualized class rated their teacher significantly higher than students in the larger group, and stated that their ability to organize their work increased. The scores of the two groups of students were not significantly different on the following tests: "American Chemical Society Cooperative Examination-General Chemistry", "Test on Understanding Science, Watson-Glaser Critical Thinking Appraisal", the "Prouse Subject Preference", six CBA achievement tests, and the final examination. (Author/AL)
References.QuickCitation: Krockover Gerald Howard (1970) A comparison of learning outcomes in CBA chemistry when group and individualized instruction techniques are employed.. , The University of Iowa.

References.Title: The Effect of Cooperative and Mastery Learning Methods on Primary Grade Students' Learning and Retention of Economic Concepts
References.Abstract: Empirical studies have shown the positive effects of combining cooperative and mastery learning methods on mathematics achievement higher order questioning skills, and originality, but little is known, at present, about the effects of cooperative-mastery learning in other subject areas or on other cognitive outcomes. The problem of this study was to explore the effects of cooperative and mastery learning methods, alone and in combination, on first and second grade students' learning and retention of basic economic concepts. A 2 X 2 (cooperative X mastery) factorial design compared the achievement of one hundred-twenty students who were individually randomly assigned (using grade level as a stratification variable) to one of four treatment conditions?instruction on basic economic concepts using (1) cooperative learning, (2) mastery learning, (3) cooperative-mastery learning, or (4) a control treatment (no cooperative or mastery learning). All subjects were administered a written pretest, post-test, and delayed post-test on their understanding of economic concepts. To further probe children's understanding of economic concepts, a randomly selected sub-sample of sixty- four students was interviewed using an oral pretest, post-test, and delayed post-test. Overall, the results support the superiority of the cooperative-mastery learning method over either method alone in promoting the acquisition and retention of economic concepts. Pretest data verified the initial equivalence of groups. The cooperative-mastery learning group outperformed (a) the control group on all post-tests and delayed post-tests and (b) the cooperative learning group on all post-tests and delayed post-tests except the written post-test. By delayed post-test on the oral measure, the cooperative-mastery learning group was also outperforming the mastery learning group. As further evidence of the superiority of the cooperative-mastery learning method, the mean score of the cooperative-mastery learning group was greater than the combined mean scores of the mastery and cooperative learning groups on the oral post-test and delayed post-test. The authors suggest that the cooperative-mastery learning method is in line with current early childhood practices and has the capacity for simultaneously boosting the conceptual development and language development of young children. This capacity is said to stem from the method's provision of (a) specific, positive feedback, (b) a social context for sustained effort and involvement in a topic, (c) child?child communication exchanges, and (d) adult?child communication exchanges.

References.Title: An Investigation into the Effects of a Modified Mastery Strategy on Achievement in a High School Human Physiology Unit.
References.ParentTitle: Journal of Research in Science Teaching
References.Abstract: Determined if modifying Bloom's mastery strategy improves science achievement during a six week human physiology unit. Findings indicate only a small degree of improvement in achievement of 185 students. Suggests that the approach employed in this study would be impractical for the biology classroom. (DS)

References.Title: Effects of selected mastery learning strategies in terms of articulation problems in French 3 classes at Bellevue High School.
References.Abstract: This study was conducted to determine whether selected mastery learning strategies might serve as a partial solution to articulation problems in level 3 French. The central question posited was one of determining whether certain desired learning outcomes (and those logically related to smooth program articulation) were encouraged by the utilization of selected mastery learning strategies. Specifically, the investigation was directed to two related questions: 1) Can mastery learning strategies lead to achievement gains? and 2) Can these strategies at the same time produce a lesser variance in student achievement? Two null hypotheses related to the amount of learning and one null hypothesis related to the variability of posttest scores were developed. The selected mastery learning strategies used in the study were additional information about the content and expectations of each unit of work before the work was begun, frequent testing and detailed feedback on the results of the tests, and extra attempts to improve performance on tests. The researcher also considered the practicality of applying mastery learning strategies to secondary school instruction in terms of time constraints of a traditionally scheduled school, required alterations in the curriculum, amount of teacher time required for planning and evaluation, and identification of strategies critical to success. Seventy-four students taking level 3 French comprised the research sample. The MLA-Cooperative Foreign Language Tests were administered at the beginning of the study and students were randomly assigned on a matchedpair basis to a control or an experimental group on the basis of measures of competence in listening, speaking, reading, and writing. After ten weeks of instruction, parallel forms of the standardized test were administered to measure gains made during the research period and to determine the variability of students' competencies as indicated by posttest scores. Statistical analyses of the data (t-tests and analyses of variance) indicated that 1) subjects in both groups made significant gains in listening, speaking, and writing, but not in reading; 2) that subjects were not significantly different with regard to the mean gain scores; 3) that from analysis of the subsections of the tests, both groups were basically the same (the experimental group made significant gains on 14 of the subsections while the control group made significant gains on 13 subsections); and 4) that there was no significant difference between the variability of the posttest scores for the two groups.

[¬s]"unit provides cues to discover a strategy that is necessary to solve the problem. The cues are given in a form of guiding questions embedded within the text (see p. 35). The students should process the prob­ lem solving strategy by answering the questions or by filling the blanks in the Student Activities. This stage of the instruction was employed by the class as a group. After each class, the student received homework assignments selected from the Additional Practice Activity. The Addi­ tional Practice Activities included a wide range of problems which varied in cognitive levels and in degree of similarity to the initial learning tasks. "
" Each unit was followed by a formative test which assessed the mastery of the objectives of that unit. The formative tests included two parts: ten multiple choice problems (five higher and five lower order items) and ten open questions (five higher and five lower items). In the "open question part" the students wrote down the specific steps of their solution. Following their detailed solution enabled the researcher to trace more carefully the sources of their mistakes.[¬e]"

The instructional materials were organized in Student Activities as was explained on p. b6 . The general pattern of instructional procedure in setting B was similar to that in setting A. In both settings the teachers reviewed the homework (5-10 minutes), introduced the new materials (20-25 minutes), and provided individual seatwork and homework assignments which were cor­ rected and graded. The students were informed of their total grade on the papers and the formative tests.[¬e]"

Usually, they called on the most responsive students and very frequently asked several students to explain the way in which they solved the problems. When a problem was solved in various ways, all the solutions were discussed. Second, the presentation of the new materials was also performed with student participation encouraged. References.Title: The Effects of Cooperative Mastery Learning Strategies on Mathematics Achievement
References.Abstract: This study investigated the effects of student-teams using mastery learning strategies (STML) on mathematics achievement of fifth-grade children (N = 134). The experiment used a 2 x 2 (Student Teams x Mastery Learning) factorial design. Results showed higher achievement gains for pupils exposed to STML than for those exposed through more traditional instruction. The data further indicated that learning in small groups promoted only computational skills whereas mastery learning strategies improved both computation and comprehension. In addition, the benefits of the methods for high-, medium-, and low-ability students were examined and discussed.

References.Title: The Effects of Cooperative Mastery Learning Strategies on Mathematics Achievement
References.Abstract: This study investigated the effects of student-teams using mastery learning strategies (STML) on mathematics achievement of fifth-grade children (N = 134). The experiment used a 2 x 2 (Student Teams x Mastery Learning) factorial design. Results showed higher achievement gains for pupils exposed to STML than for those exposed through more traditional instruction. The data further indicated that learning in small groups promoted only computational skills whereas mastery learning strategies improved both computation and comprehension. In addition, the benefits of the methods for high-, medium-, and low-ability students were examined and discussed.
References.Comments: MDE: Please code MLS versus control (Mastery learning – individual condition)ESDE: Comprehension as primary outcome and Computation as secondary outcome.

References.Title: Learning Mathematics in Different Mastery Environments
References.Abstract: The purpose of the present study was threefold: (a) to examine the effects of cooperative-mastery learning (CML) strategies on mathematics achievement of low-socioeconomic (SES) students; (b) to investigate the relative contributions of the mastery versus the cooperative components on achievement; and (c) to explore student interactions in CML (the why of learning, not only the what). Two experiments were conducted. In the first experiment, intact classes were randomly assigned to one of four treatment groups: mastery learning (ML), cooperative learning (CL), cooperative-mastery learning (CML), and a control group with no mastery and no cooperative strategies. Results showed that students exposed to CML performed better than students exposed through more traditional instruction. In the second experiment, student interactions in CML were observed and linked to achievement. The data indicated significant differences between high and low achievers on giving help, receiving help, and individualized learning, but not on receiving no response to requests for help. The regression equation showed that initial achievement, giving help, and receiving help explained 98% of the variance in achievement. © 1991 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
References.Comments: MDE: Please focus in comparing scores between Mastery learning vs. the control group.
References.QuickCitation: Mevarech Z R (1991) Learning Mathematics in Different Mastery Environments. Journal of Educational Research 84(4), 225-232 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220671.1991.10886019

[¬s]"Mastery learning (ML): In contrast to previous mas
tery-learning studies in which the feedback correctives
focused on achievement, in the present mastery learning
setting, feedback correctives focused on questioning be
haviors. Thus, in the ML setting, children first read the
text, interpreted it, and worked on the seatwork activi
ties using the booklets and the games specially designed
for this setting. The seatwork activities aimed at training
children to generate lower and higher cognitive ques
tions as described above. At the end of each subunit, the
ML teacher read children's papers and provided each
pupil with feedback concerning his or her self-generated
questions. Pupils who performed below a pre-set criteri
on level of mastery were required to re-do the work and
improve the skill. For example, students who generated
a smaller number of HCQ than a pre-set criterion (usu
ally four questions) were asked to generate more ques
tions at this level. (The mastery criteria were established
on the basis of a pilot study that indicated the average
number of questions children produced on each para
graph.) The seatwork activities were used in individual
ized settings.[¬e]"

Page 4:
[¬s]"Questioning skills were assessed by a questioning skill
instrument (QSI) (Forms A and B) constructed by the
authors on the basis of the study of Berlyne and From
mer (1966). The QSI includes a picture and a short
story, each depicting an aspect of the content learned in
the classroom. The picture was administered first. Pu
pils were instructed to look carefully at the picture and
write as many questions as they had about it. When they
finished, the short story was administered to all pupils,
and the same procedure was repeated. The order was
chosen on the basis of a pilot study showing that pupils
were more motivated to generate questions when the
picture was presented first than when the order was re
versed. Additionally, the pilot study indicated no signif
icant differences between Forms A and B on the number
and cognitive levels of the pupil-generated questions.
Pupils' questions regarding the picture and the short
story were separately classified into the six cognitive cat
egories of Bloom's taxonomy (1956). To simplify the re
port, factual and comprehension questions were classi
fied into lower cognitive questions (LCQ), and analysis,
synthesis, and evaluative queries were classified into
higher cognitive questions (HCQ) (none of the questions
concerned application). This classification is in accord
with previous research by Gall (1976) and Gall, Ward,
Berliner, Cohen, Winne, Elashoff, and Stanton (1984).
Interrater reliability coefficients were .90 and .86 for the
picture and text respectively.
Creativity was assessed by Forms A and B of Tor
rance Test of Creative Thinking: "Improving a Toy"
(1966). Scores were given on measures of fluency (the
number of relevant responses), flexibility (the number
of different approaches used in producing ideas for im
provement), and originality (the statistical infrequency
of the ideas produced). Interrater reliability coefficients
were .98, .81, and .80 for fluency, flexibility, and origi
nality, respectively.
Achievement on the curriculum unit content was ex
amined by a 20-item multiple-choice test that was con
structed by the teachers and the researchers for our
study. KR(21) reliability coefficient was .84.[¬e]"

References.Title: Effects of Learning with Cooperative-Mastery Method on Elementary Students
References.Abstract: The present study examined the effects of the cooperative-mastery method and each of its components on children's questioning behavior, creativity, and achievement. A 2 × 2 (Cooperative x Mastery) factorial study compared the cognitive performances of pupus who were trained to generate questions under cooperative learning (CL), mastery learning (ML), cooperative-mastery learning (CML), and a control treatment. Participants were 271 third and fourth-grade pupils. Intact classes within each grade level were randomly assigned to one of the four treatment groups. Results showed that CML and ML pupils scored higher on measures of higher order questioning skills and originality than did the CL group, who, in turn, scored higher than the control group. The educational implications of the study are discussed. © 1993 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
References.Comments: MDE: Please focus in comparing the ML vs. the control group.           ESDE: using adjusted means Curriculum Unit as primary outcome, fluency, flexibility and originality (Torrance standardised test of creativity) as secondary outcomes.
References.QuickCitation: Mevarech Z R, and Susak Z (1993) Effects of Learning with Cooperative-Mastery Method on Elementary Students. Journal of Educational Research 86(4), 197-205 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220671.1993.9941831

Page 68:

Recognition of students with respect to performance focused on individual effort,
progress, and improvement. Comparison of students based on performance was not done
in the classroom. Grades were not posted or students ranked according to scores on
assessments. Student recognition was done privately and focused on the quality of
student work and not the quantity. On graded assignments and assessments individualized
and detailed evaluative feedback was given to the students emphasizing improvements,
accomplishments, and mastery of the content. Grades were based on a scale of 60 to 100.
A grade of 60 - 69 indicates that the student has not mastered the content or does not
meet expectations. A grade of 70 - 79 indicates the student has mastered a portion of the
content but needs improvement. A grade of 80 - 89 indicates mastery of the content and
the student meets expectations. A grade of 90 - 100 indicates the student exceeds
expectations for mastery of the content.[¬e]"

All participants took pretest-posttest assessments, using a computer testing
program STAR Math, to determine academic achievement levels. STAR Math is a norm-
referenced computer-adaptive assessment, which assesses each student’s mathematical
computation, application, and concept skills. The assessment included each student’s
grade-equivalency (GE), percentile rank, and normal curve equivalency scores, which
were developed from the scaled score. This study used the STAR Math scaled score as
the measurement of student academic achievement in mathematics; since scaled scores
are useful in comparing student performance over time and are criterion-referenced in[¬e]"

[¬s]"Motivational Orientation Inventory (MOI)
The MOI was used during the repeated-measures component of the study to
determine the participants’ academic motivational orientation toward mathematics: (a)
mastery (task) goal orientation, (b) performance-approach orientation, and (c)
performance-avoidance goal orientation. Additionally, the MOI determined the
participants’ perceptions of classroom goal structures, and academic efficacy. A sample
of the modified Likert-style self-survey is in (Appendix A). The response scales on the
survey range from 1 = Not At All True to 5 = Very True. The self-survey contained 34
self-response items.[¬e]"

Page 56:
[¬s]"Deemer (2004) uses a TARGET conceptual framework, based on the work of
Ames (1992) and others, to model how teachers can create classroom environments that
are focused on meaningful learning using mastery goals. While performance related goals
are pervasive in secondary classrooms, there is a need for the implementation of mastery
goals. Deemer proposes six dimensions or structures in a secondary classroom
environment, which can be used to implement mastery goals and result in higher levels of
student learning and academic achievement. The TARGET framework consists of task
design (T), distribution of authority (A), recognition of students (R), instructional
grouping (G), evaluation practices (E), and time allocation (T).[¬e]"

Page 83:
[¬s]"During the treatment phase the instructionally
focused topic groups were facilitated by the teachers to remediate students struggling
with the same mathematical concept or skill. Students in the topic groups received
targeted instruction and remediation based on formative and summative assessments
given to the students.
Targeted instruction consisted of teacher facilitated remediation in instructionally
focused topic groups. Students in these groups received instruction consisting of in-depth[¬e]"

Page 84:
[¬s]"coverage of each problem type (4-6 problems), followed by distributed-guided practice,
and individualized student practice. Following remediation the students were reassessed
to determine mastery of the content using another form of the previous assessment.
Students needing remediation also worked with peer tutors to master concepts.[¬e]"

Page 58:
[¬s]"Evaluation or the methods to assess and monitor student
learning should be diverse and give the students opportunities to improve their work
(Deemer, 2004). Mastery goals are promoted when assessment is focused on individual
progress, improvement, and understanding. Both summative and formative evaluation
practices should be used. Summative evaluation practices should include not only
traditional tests, but also portfolios, presentations, completion and understanding of
homework or class work, and quality of work. Grades should not be based on
performance relative to others. Instead, the focus of grades needs to be based on effort,
improvement, and achieving a standard[¬e]"

References.Title: Mastery Learning and Academic Achievement
References.Abstract: During the 2006-2007 school year, 14% of the eighth-grade mathematics students at the study campus failed to meet advancement criteria on the Georgia Criterion Referenced Competency Test (CRCT). The purpose of this quantitative pretest-posttest and control-group design study was to first investigate the effects of a mastery goal approach to instruction on eighth-grade mathematic students’ academic ability, and also to examine the effects of the treatment on motivational constructs. For the first portion of the study, two groups of students, 43 in the control group and 36 in the treatment group, were examined to determine the effect of the treatment on the participants’ academic achievement on the STAR Math assessment. An independent-measures t test was used to evaluate the mean difference (MD ) in the scaled scores gains from STAR Math assessments to determine academic achievement, which indicated the treatment group had significantly higher achievement gains than the control group, MD = 32.44, p < .001, and d = .53. Next, a repeated-measures study of 57 students used a Motivational Orientation Inventory (MOI) as a pretest and posttest to determine any changes, as a result of the treatment, on the students’ academic motivational orientation, perceptions of classroom goal structures, and academic efficacy. Paired-samples t tests were conducted on the mean of each motivational construct in the MOI with the results indicating significant changes in the students’ performance-avoidance goal orientation. Findings can be used to enhance positive social change by providing mastery learning structures including individualized student pacing of instruction, remediation and retesting of standards, and student assessment based on mastery of material in order to motivate students to learn and promote higher levels of academic achievement.

References.Title: The Effect of Flexible Modular Scheduling on Student Achievement in BSCS Biology.
References.Abstract: Reported is a study to compare the achievement of selected 10th-grade biology students on a traditional schedule with selected 10th-grade biology students on a flexible modular schedule. Both groups studied the blue version of the Biological Sciences Curriculum Study (BSCS) materials. Students were paired in the groups on the basis of their scores on Test 2, Background in Natural Sciences, and the composite of the Iowa Tests of Educational Development. Achievement was measured by use of the BSCS Comprehensive Final Examination for first year biology students. Additional data came from scores on the Brown-Holtzman Survey of Study Habits. Twenty-nine matched pairs of students were involved in the final data analysis. No significant differences were found in achievement; in study habits, study attitudes, and study orientation; nor did school organizational type affect student achievement in BSCS biology. (Author/PEB)

Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: The test was developed by the COPES evaluation staff. Written copies of the instruments were distributed to the students and the class worked on one item at a time. Each student was supplied with a copy of the test. The teacher read each item to the class prior to their writing their answers.

References.Title: A comparison of the effectiveness of two methods of presenting science experiments to children of the fourth grade in a northeastern suburb.
References.Abstract: The study describes the effectiveness of teaching as prescribed by the Conceptually Oriented Program in Elementary Science (COPES) program compared to an audio-tutorial approach at the fourth grade level. The experimental group covered the COPES content but with audio-tutorial materials prepared by the investigator. No significant differences were found between the achievement scores of the experimental subjects and control subjects. A significant difference existed between the amount of time spent by the two groups on the sequence of activities. Children in the experimental group took significantly less time to complete the activities. (PS)
References.QuickCitation: Netburn Allan N (1972) A comparison of the effectiveness of two methods of presenting science experiments to children of the fourth grade in a northeastern suburb.. , New York University.

References.Title: The effects of different qualities of instruction on selected cognitive, affective, and time variables.
References.Abstract: Purpose: The major purpose of the study was to determine the effects of enhancing the different components of the quality of instruction on achievement in mathematics, affect for mathematics and involvement in learning. The study also examined the effects of intelligence and aptitude on achievement under these different instructional procedures.Procedure: The sample of this study consisted of 328 sixth grade students drawn from six shools in the state of Perak in Malaysia. An experimental control group design was adopted. The investigation used one control and four experimental groups enhanced cue, enhanced participation, enhanced cue-participation and feedback corrective. The actual experiment took approximately one month to complete. Results: The first hypothesis was to investigate the effects of enhancing cue and participation singly and in combination on involvement and learning outcomes. It was found that the means of involvement, achievement and affect for mathematics for the enhanced groups were significantly higher than those of the control group. It was also found that the feedback-corrective group was significantly higher than the enhanced groups on each of the criterion measures. The study investigated the effects of intelligence and mathematics aptitude on achievement under the different instructional conditions. Under the control condition, the relationship between achievement and prior ability measures was very high. However, the effects of prior ability measures on achievement were markedly diminished under feedback-corrective as well as under each of the enhanced qualities of instruction condition. The study also demonstrated that involvement in learning acted as a mediating variable between entry characteristics and learning outcomes. As involvement changed achievement and affect also changed, both positively and negatively. Conclusions: On the basis of the findings the following conclusions were made. Quality of instruction is a potentially powerful determinant of the levels of achievement, affect for the subject and involvement in learning. Enhancing the different components of the quality of instruction resulted in significantly higher learning than when these components were not enhanced. However, supplementing group instruction with feedback-corrective procedures resulted in significantly higher learning than enhancing the components of quality of instruction. The problem for further research is to determine how much more effective learning can be if improvements are made on each of the enhancement procedures or if all the components of quality of instruction are enhanced simultaneously. The goal of such research is to do as well as or surpass the presnet maximally effective instruction -- the feedback-corrective procedure.
References.Comments: This study has 4 experimental groups and 1 control. According to the author the feedback corrective group is the mastery learning group. Please focus on comparing data between the feedback corrective and the control group. Table 12 provides the achievement data.
References.QuickCitation: Nordin Abu Bakar (1979) The effects of different qualities of instruction on selected cognitive, affective, and time variables.. , The University of Chicago.

"A critical component of mastery teaching is frequent diagnostic testing. Instead of testing at the end of a unit, say every two or three weeks, pupils are tested as soon as they finish a short bit of instruction. References.Title: Altering Teacher and Pupil Behavior with Mastery Teaching
References.Abstract: This study's main purpose was to determine the effects a mastery teaching strategy would have on pupil achievement. Page 1:
[¬s]" He describes a learning strategy to accomplish mastery of subject matter that places heavy emphasis on frequent assessment of student progress, followed by additional instruction for those students that need it. Typically, classroom instruction is conducted for those students followed by a summative test on a unit. Upon comple- tion of the test a new unit begins. In a classroom where mastery learning is being used, short diagnostic tests based on course objectives are given every day or two. If students do not achieve the objectives, they are given additional materials to study so that minor learning problems can be remedied before they become major ones.[¬e]"

References.Title: Consequences of Training Teachers to Use a Mastery Learning Strategy
References.Abstract: The purpose of this project was to produce materials that would foster favorable teacher attitudes toward the philosophy behind mastery learning. One other purpose was to help teachers acquire the skills needed to use mastery learning in their classrooms and to determine the effects on pupils when mastery learning techniques were used. Forty-four teachers and interns from four Indianapolis schools were equally divided into groups according to race and sex. The material developed was a Mastery Teaching module which included an introduction and six sections. A slide/tape accompanied each of the seven parts. An accompanying manual contained objectives, practice exercises, and feedback. The manual also included self-tests with answers for each section, a pre-test on prerequisites, and a project section. Pre- and post-treatment measures were administered to the teachers and interns on both cognitive and affective variables. The results indicated that teachers and interns acquired the mastery teaching skills and, used them to the degree that pupils perceived differences in their teaching. Teacher attitudes toward the mastery teaching philosophy were generally positive, and students' attitudes and achievement were favorably altered because of their teachers' use of mastery teaching. (DT)

References.Title: Development and evaluation of an individualized learning unit in science for the junior high school
References.Abstract: This study involved the development of a conceptually oriented curriculum framework in science for grades seven through nine, the individualization of one learning unit selected from the framework, and the design of an investigation to analyze change in the acquisition of subject matter content between students in individualized and in lecture/demonstration-centered patterns of instruction. The subject matter content consisted of scientific facts and principles embraced by the concept Matter Is Particulate. Fifty-eight classes were selected from six junior high schools in the Jordan and Weber School Districts to participate in the study. Class enrollment ranged from 16 students in one class to 41 in another. Of the 58 classes selected, 31 were taught by individualized patterns of instruction with a mastery learning orientation; the remaining 27 classes were taught by lecture/demonstration-centered patterns of instruction. The 58 classes were taught by 23 different teachers. During the Fall of 1969, the students participated in a pretesting program which included a subject matter achievement test and a mental maturity (l.Q.) test. The post-testing program, conducted nine to twelve weeks later, involved the administration of an alternate form of the same achievement test to determine student gains in subject matter content. The curriculum framework, which included an outline of the major scientific principles embraced by the concept Matter Is Particulate, was given to each teacher in both the individualized and the lecture/demonstration-centered patterns of instruction. The subject matter outline was Identical for both groups. Data used in this study were obtained from three tests whose validity and reliability were well established: Interaction of Matter and Energy Experimental Achievement Test Interaction of Matter and Energy Achievement Test, and the Verbal Reasoning and Numerical Abilities sections of the Differential Aptitude Tests battery. The following conclusions were drawn from the data analyzed in this investigation. 1. There was a relationship, significant at the .001 level, between the acquisition of subject matter content and the method of instruction. Students in individualized classes earned higher gain scores on the achievement test than those in lecture/demonstration-centered classes. 2. There was a significant relationship at the .001 level between the acquisition of subject matter content and the I.Q. level of the student. Students with high mental ability made higher gain scores than those with lower mental ability. 3. There was no significant relationship between the subject matter content and the following factors: (a) sex; (b) method and sex; (c) method and I.Q. level; and (d) method, I.Q. level, and sex. 4. There was a significant relationship at the .01 level between the subject matter content and a combination of I.Q. level and sex.

[¬s]"uggestions for Implementation When implementing a diagnostic-prescriptive unit there are two overall considerations: preplanning and adequate use of classroom time. When planning an instructional unit, objectives must be developed along with correspond ing diagnostic quizzes, summative tests, and remedial activities. The time needed to develop a unit can be con siderable but the materials can be used again in subse quent years. In a sense, the more that materials are used, the less the cost. To use class time efficiently, a schedule must be planned and followed. A specific amount of time must be designated for instruction, diagnostic quizzes, and remediation when needed.[¬e]"

References.Title: Diagnosis, Remediation, and Locus of Control
References.Abstract: The influence of locus of control, diagnosis, and remediation on immediate and retained achievement and attitudes of middle school science students was the focus of this study. Subjects in the experiment were assessed for locus of control and experienced one of three treatments: no diagnosis or remediation; diagnosis with no remediation; or, diagnosis and remediation. Immediate achievement was measured at two points during the experiment, and retention was measured 30 days following the experiment. Diagnosis and remediation proved to be significantly effective in increasing retained achievement. Internal locus of control subjects out-scored external subjects in the areas of both immediate and retained achievement. Whites achieved higher than blacks in retention. Attitudes of all groups tended to be positive. These findings suggest that diagnostic or diagnostic and remedial instruction is an effective means of increasing the retention level of middle school students.
References.Comments: There are 3 groups in this study (T1 serves as control group and T2 and T3 as treatment groups). Please focus in coding T1 vs. T2.
References.QuickCitation: Saunders-Harris Ramona, and Yeany Russell H (1981) Diagnosis, Remediation, and Locus of Control. The Journal of Experimental Education 49(4), 220-224 DOI: https://doi.org/10.1080/00220973.1981.11011787

philosophy of "mastery teaching." This philosophy arise"
"from the belief that possibly as many as 95% of the stu
dents could achieve that which is expected of them if given
the opportunity, enough time, and feedback (1). Mastery
teaching is characterized by specific objectives to guide the
students' learning, diagnostic tests for feedback, and reme
diation on objectives not attained.
Recent research indicates that when diagnosis is used
along with remedial teaching student achievement and
retention is increased (4, 5, 7). Goodson and Okey (2)
found that diagnosis used with objectives increased stu
dents' retention and Yeany, Waugh, and Blalock (9)
reported that feedback from diagnostic quizzes positively
influenced science achievement.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"When considering diagnostic-remedial teaching and
locus of control, many questions arise. The following three
questions provide the focus of this study :
Is diagnostic-remedial teaching an effective
method for increasing achievement of middle
school science students?
Are the effects on achievement brought about
by diagnostic-remedial teaching consistent for
both black and white students?
Will the internally controlled student use the
feedback in a way that will facilitate achievement
better than a student with an external locus of
control?
The purposes of this study were to assess the effects of
diagnostic-remedial teaching, locus of control, and race on
the immediate and retained achievement of middle-school
science students.[¬e]"

as "external": and, those people who believe that each per
son determines his course in life, where luck and destiny
are just excuses, are referred to as "internal." It is possible

References.Title: Student Teams and Mastery Learning: A Factorial Experiment in Urban Math Nine Classes.
References.Abstract: Mastery Learning and Student Team Learning are two widely used instructional methods designed to confront the problem of student diversity in group-paced instruction. This study evaluated Mastery Learning, Student Team Learning, and a combination, in 43 inner-city math nine classes over a full school year. Results indicated greater achievement on a standardized test for Team classes than non-Team classes, but no greater achievement in Mastery than non-Mastery classes. Differences in time use were suggested to explain treatment differences in student achievement. (Author/MP)
References.Comments: Five treatment conditions: 1) Mastery, 2) Mastery + Teams, 3) Teams, 4) Focussed Instruction, 5) Control. Please compare the mastery vs. the control (non-mastery classes)Please use the WS (Slavin) 1982c version for highlighting.

References.Title: Mastery Learning and Student Teams: A Factorial Experiment in Urban General Mathematics Classes
References.Abstract: The mathematics achievement effects of principal components of mastery learning and student team learning were evaluated in a year-long randomized experiment in urban ninth grade general mathematics classes. The components were formative tests, corrective instruction for nonmasters, summative tests (Mastery), and practice in four-member heterogeneous teams and team rewards (Teams). A 2 X 2 (Mastery by Teams) factorial experiment compared Mastery, Teams, Teams + Mastery, and a control treatment. All methods used the same materials and schedule of teaching, worksheets, and test. A nested analysis of covariance indicated significant achievement main effects for Teams but not for Mastery. No Mastery by Teams or pretest by treatment interactions were found.
References.Comments: MDE: Please compare Mastery versus Focussed instruction (active control) for Mastery learning, post-test only as primary outcome, mathematics achievement (Table 1).

elements of the Teams treatment and Mastery treatment just described. In
the Teams and Mastery treatment, the classes were taught using the
following sequence: teaching, team study, formative quiz, corrective in-[¬e]"

Page 6:
[¬s]"struction within teams, and summative quiz. Students who did not achieve
the 80% mastery criterion on the formative test received corrective instruc-
tion within their teams. After corrective instruction, they took the sum-
mative quiz, and all team members' summative quiz scores were formed
into team scores as in the Teams treatment."
"Focused Instruction. This treatment served as the control group in the
factorial design. Classes used a schedule of instruction as follows: teaching,
individual worksheets, and quiz. This treatment thus differed from the
Mastery treatment in that no corrective instruction or summative quiz was
given. It differed from the Teams treatment in that students worked
individually and did not receive team recognition.[¬e]"

Page 2:
[¬s]"Mastery learning (Bloom, 1976; Block & Burns, 1976), one of the most
widely used alternatives to traditional teaching methods, focuses primarily
on students' abilities to understand instruction by attempting to insure
that all students have mastered the previous skill before attempting the
next.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"The purpose of the present research was to investigate the separate and
combined effects of the principal components of mastery learning and
team learning on student mathematics achievement. Slavin (1984) argued
that to be effective, instructional methods must adequately provide for the
four alterable elements of Carroll's (1963) model: appropriate levels of
instruction (ability to understand instruction), incentives (perseverance),
time (opportunity), and quality of instruction. In this view, these elements
are multiplicatively related to achievement; if any one is inadequate,
achievement will be low. Therefore, it was hypothesized in the present
study that by combining the principal components of a program directed
at improving ability to understand instruction (mastery learning) and a
program directed at incentives for learning (team learning), achievement
would be increased more than would be expected on the basis of the effects
of each component separately."
"Another widely used alternative to traditional group-paced instruction
is student team learning (Slavin, 1983a, 1983b). This term refers to a set
of instructional methods in which students study material initially pre-
sented by the teacher in four-member heterogeneous learning teams, and
are rewarded based on average team performance on individually admin-
istered quizzes or other assessments. These methods are principally directed
at increasing student perseverance by providing incentives (i.e., team
rewards) for students to encourage and help one another to master aca-
demic materials.[¬e]"

[¬s]"Trained behavioral observers and other research staff conducted regular
implementation checks to be sure that all teachers were implementing
their assigned methods. Minimum requirements were established for ade-
quate implementation. These were the use of formative quizzes, corrective
instruction, and summative quizzes in the Mastery treatments, the use of
heterogeneous teams, team scores, and team recognition in the Teams
treatments, and the use of a regular schedule of teaching, worksheet work,
and quiz in all treatments, including Focused Instruction. All teachers
were found to be using these major components of their assigned treatments
adequately, although the quality of implementation varied widely.[¬e]"

Page 9:
[¬s]"The implementation of the Mastery technique in this study did not seem
to be problematic. The researchers generally found instruction to be
adequate and the classes relatively orderly, and, as noted earlier, teachers
generally implemented their assigned treatments appropriately. Although
there were many implementation problems inevitable in depressed inner
city schools, they did not appear to be serious enough to explain the
disappointing findings for the Mastery component. The Teams classes
suffered from similar implementation problems, yet this component was
found to be effective in increasing achievement.[¬e]"

their assigned method, but a few taught more than one class.[¬e]"

Page 1:
[¬s]"there has been considerable research on instruc-
tion based in large part on Carroll's (1963) model of school learning.
Carroll's model expressed the degree of learning as a function of time spent
learning and time needed to learn. It proposed five elements as critical
determinants of students' rates of learning: (a) aptitude, (b) ability to
understand instruction, (c) perseverance (i.e., engaged time on task), (d)
opportunity (i.e., allocated instructional time), and (e) quality of instruc-
tion.[¬e]"

Page 2:
[¬s]"Slavin (1984) noted that Carroll's model contains elements that are
primarily internal to students (especially aptitude, ability to understand
instruction, and perseverance) and elements that are under the control of
the teacher or school, which are thus directly alterable elements of instruc-
tion. For example, ability to understand instruction is partly a function of
student aptitude (which is difficult to alter in the short run), but may be
addressed by adapting instruction to individual levels of preparedness, as
in individualized instruction programs. A student's perseverance may be
partly a function of stable personality traits or abilities, but also can be
altered by means of incentives or management strategies. Opportunity and
quality of instruction are directly alterable components of instruction.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"Slavin (1984) argued
that to be effective, instructional methods must adequately provide for the
four alterable elements of Carroll's (1963) model: appropriate levels of
instruction (ability to understand instruction), incentives (perseverance),
time (opportunity), and quality of instruction. In this view, these elements
are multiplicatively related to achievement; if any one is inadequate,
achievement will be low. Therefore, it was hypothesized in the present
study that by combining the principal components of a program directed
at improving ability to understand instruction (mastery learning) and a
program directed at incentives for learning (team learning), achievement
would be increased more than would be expected on the basis of the effects
of each component separately. T[¬e]"

Page 2:
[¬s]"The most typical mastery learning programs in elementary
and secondary schools are group-paced methods based to one degree or
another on procedures described by Block and Anderson (1975). In group-
paced mastery learning, initial instruction is followed by a formative test.
Students who do not pass this test at a designated level (e.g., 80-90%
correct) receive corrective instruction, followed by a summative test.
Students who fail the summative test may receive further instruction until
all students finally pass, or the teacher may decide to move on when a
specified proportion of the class has demonstrated mastery of the unit.[¬e]"

Codes.AdditionalText: Mastery goals seem to be applied at an individual level, although students receive corrective instruction in groups

Outcomes.Title: Comprehensive Test of Basic Skills - Mathematics subscales
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: A shortened version of the Mathematics Computations and Concepts and Applications subscales of the Comprehensive Test of Basic Skills (CTBS), Level 2, Form S served as the achievement measure. Every third item was taken from the CTBS to create a 30-item test, which could be taken in one class period. The raw number correct was used as the achievement measure.

OutcomeItemAttributesList.AttributeName: Post-test unadjusted (select one from this group)

References.Title: Mastery Learning and Student Teams: A Factorial Experiment in Urban General Mathematics Classes
References.Abstract: The mathematics achievement effects of principal components of mastery learning and student team learning were evaluated in a year-long randomized experiment in urban ninth grade general mathematics classes. The components were formative tests, corrective instruction for nonmasters, summative tests (Mastery), and practice in four-member heterogeneous teams and team rewards (Teams). A 2 X 2 (Mastery by Teams) factorial experiment compared Mastery, Teams, Teams + Mastery, and a control treatment. All methods used the same materials and schedule of teaching, worksheets, and test. A nested analysis of covariance indicated significant achievement main effects for Teams but not for Mastery. No Mastery by Teams or pretest by treatment interactions were found.
References.Comments: MDE: Please compare Teams and Mastery versus Focussed instruction (active control).ESDE: Post-test only as primary outcome, mathematics achievement (Table 1). In the strand specific this will be individual level mastery learning.
References.Authors: Slavin Robert E; Karweit Nancy L;

References.Title: The effects of individualized learning activity packages in mathematics on the academic achievement of seventh and eighth grade students in the Demopolis City School
References.Abstract: This study investigate the effect of individualized learning activity packages in mathematics on the academic achievement of seventh- and eighth-grade students. Both seventh- and eighth-grade students in the Demopolis Junior High School had learning activity packages (LAP) provided. Each student was given a folder which contained the packages being used and each student maintained a cumulative summary of his progress, showing both the LAP covered and its level of difficulty. Conditions and performance of LAP objectives were established by the teacher and the particular learner. Students were tested for mastery before each LAP and provided with diagnostic feedback to ensure the correct level was assigned.  Post-tests designed for each difficulty level on each LAP sub-category provided the means for determining satisfactory completion of a specific learning activity package. Non-LAP instruction in mathematics consisted of the conventional lecture-discussion method with the provision of textbook exercises. The instrument used to measure the academic growth of students in LAP and non-LAP instruction in mathematics was the California Achievement Tests, 1970 edition.  The four control variables used in matching students were: (1) chronological age, (2) sex, (3) race, and (4) intelligence quotient. On this basis, fifty-eight students were matched so as to provide twenty-nine pairs. Twelve pairs (n = 24) comprised the seventh-grade sample and seventeen pairs (n = 34) made up the eighth-grade sample. Analysis of variance was utilized in looking for significant differences in academic achievement between the two treatments at each of the two grade levels. An examination of treatment means revealed that in grade eight students undergoing conventional classroom instruction consistently had a mean greater than those utilizing Learning Activity Packages. In no case was such a difference statistically significant at .05. By levels in grade eight, there were no statistically significant differences at .05. Treatment means in grade seven indicated that students achieved greater academic growth in LAP than in conventional classroom instruction. At no time, however, were differences significant at .05. No F values were significant at .05 in relation to levels nor to interaction (treatments x levels) in grade seven.

References.Title: A feasibility study of tutorial type computer assisted instruction in selected topics in high school chemistry.
References.Abstract: A study was performed to determine the effectiveness of short-term, tutorial-type computer-assisted instruction (CAI) in selected topics in high school chemistry. To determine CAI effectiveness, post-tests specifically designed for this study were administered at the completion of instruction and sixty days later. Control group students generally performed 20% higher than did CAI students on both post-tests. The CAI group, however, appeared to learn twice as fast, completing the chemistry program in from one-third to one-half the time required by classroom students. The increased learning rate called for self-pacing and meaningful time usage not ordinarily encountered in traditional instruction; students in CAI felt challenged to productivity. Students were favorably impressed by computer-assisted instruction in general. (RB)
References.QuickCitation: Summerlin Lee Roy (1971) A feasibility study of tutorial type computer assisted instruction in selected topics in high school chemistry.. , University of Maryland, College Park.

general. The five-day period allotted for relearning and retesting in this investigation was very
liberal, considering that both PSI and Mastery Learning strategies suggest one or tw
additional days per instructional unit as sufficient time for remediation.[¬e]"

References.Title: A comparison of mastery learning feedback systems, affecting achievement in chemistry
References.ParentTitle: The Annual Meeting of the American Educational Research Association (ERIC Document Rekoduction Service No. ED 139 650)
References.Abstract: The effectiveness of a Keller and Bloom mastery learning program for high school science students was examined by comparing remediation strategies of both programs and that of a traditional strategy. The data gathered in the experiment in chemistry were from a pre- and post-achievement test. Cognitive achievement was statistically different (p < .025). Additional analysis revealed the greatest difference was between a Bloom and a traditional strategy. Gain score analyses failed to produce any significant differences. A Chi-square analysis of the number of objectives achieved produced significant values of .004 and .034, respectively, for the Keller and Bloom groups over the traditional group.
References.Comments: This study has 3 groups.  The control, Keller condition and Bloom condition. Please code control vs. Keller condition.

References.Title: A method of group instruction which is as effective as one-to-one tutorial instruction.
References.Abstract: The major purpose of the research was to develop a group instruction method which is as effective as a one-to-one tutorial method, and, to determine the extent to which cognitive and affective outcomes of learning are affected by the instructional conditions provided to students. Three different group instructional conditions were used in the studies: (a) enhanced cues, participation, reinforcement, and feedback-corrective procedure, a maximal group instruction, (b) conventional group instruction, a minimal quality which is not equally adaptive to individual needs of most students, and (3) mastery learning, a quality which lies between the two extremes and uses the feedback-corrective procedure. Two studies were conducted in two different content areas and two grade levels. The results of the two studies indicate that the achievement students attain, the attitudes they acquire toward themselves as learners, and toward various aspects of school learning as well as the relations between prior and subsequent achievement are strongly determined by the instructional conditions provided to students. Seventy-four percent of students under maximal group instruction and 57 percent of the students under mastery learning conditions attained the level of final achievement reached only by the top 17 percent of the students under conventional instruction. Under maximal group instruction 69 percent of the students reached the mastery criterion (80 percent) on higher mental processes in comparison to 57 percent in the mastery learning and only 8 percent in the conventional groups. Large differences were also obtained on lower mental processes. The average student in the maximal group instruction was above 96 percent of the students in the conventional groups. In the enhanced CPR plus mastery learning and mastery learning groups the relation between prior and final achievement was very weak (about 8 percent common variance) however, under conventional conditions the relations remained strong (about 60 percent common variance). The effects of the instructional conditions on selected affective outcomes were also evident in the alteration of attitudes over the course of the study. Students under maximal group instruction became on the average, 22 percent more positive toward themselves as learners, the subject matter, teacher and school than were students under conventional instruction. The former were also more internal in taking responsibility for their learning outcomes. The mastery learning group advantage over the conventional group averaged 12 percent at the end of the study.
References.Comments: MDE: Please focus in extracting data for grade 6. Code Compare Mastery learning versus Conventional. ESDE: Use Summative assessments (Table 5)  HMP (Higher mental processes) as primary and LMP (Lower mental processes) as secondary outcomes, post-test only.
References.QuickCitation: Tenenbaum Gershon (1982) A method of group instruction which is as effective as one-to-one tutorial instruction.. , The University of Chicago.

ing each learning unit. These tests are aimed at the determination of

are provided with alternative cues, practice, and reinforcement for correct­

[¬s]"The model indicates that both cognitive achievement and
affective outcomes (affect for the subject, teacher and school, academic self-
concept, and intellectual achievement responsibility) are determined by the
quality of instruction given to students. The higher the quality of instruc­
tion, the higher is the achievement students attain and the more positive
are the affective outcomes of learning. The higher the quality of instruc­
tion, the lower is the relation between prior achievement and consequent
and final cognitive achievement. In the model these effects are due to the
fact that under higher quality of instruction, teaching is adjusted to the
cognitive and psychological needs of each student in the class, a phenomenon
missing from conventional instruction.[¬e]"

algebra at the beginning of each study.[¬e]"

ItemAttributeFullTextDetails.Text:
Page 74:
[¬s]"As described before, both treatment groups were given a formative
test following each unit. The test was short and took no more than
thirty minutes. The students were told that the purpose of the test was
to indicate any weaknesses and to assist in improving their knowledge and
confidence in the material learned. The teacher collected the completed
tests, determined the score for each student and noted the items answered
incorrectly. She reviewed the results by examining the difficulty level
of each item. This procedure provided precise information to the teacher
as to the specific difficulties the students had encountered. In the next
lesson, the teacher used different cues and explanations focusing on the
problematic items."
"Students with difficulties were encouraged to participate
and to solve problems on the board. Students who did well were asked to
help those who had difficulty. Following this procedure, the students who
had not reached a criterion of 80 percent mastery on the first test received
a second formative test (a parallel test with new items) in which only the
incorrect test items of the first set had to be answered. The teacher col­
lected the tests, checked them, and assigned a combination grade for both
tests.[¬e]"

Page 52:
[¬s]"In order to secure evidence of the quality of instruction during
the teaching-learning process two methods were used: (a) a questionnaire
was administered to students at the beginning, middle, a'I end of each
study; and (b<) observations were conducted throughout the process to
monitor the enhanced CPR and feedback-corrective group instructor. The
questionnaire (see Appendix B) gathered information about the cues, participa­
tion of students, and reinforcements used by the teacher as perceived by
the students. The questionnaire used contains thirty-six items selected
mainly from Nordin's study (1979). The questionnaire is divided into
three subscales: cues (#1-15, fifteen items), participation (#16-26, eleven
items) and reinforcement (#27-36, ten items)."
"The cues statements concentrate
on the clarify of aids, demonstrations, examples, and materials used in the
class to increase understanding and clarification of the content taught. The
participation subscale includes statements concentrating on the active
involvement of each student in the class, adequacy of time for participation,
the help students provide to each other, and the assignments given to the
students. The reinforcement statements concentrate on the teacher's response
to students' work and participation, teacher's praise, criticism and cor­
rections, teacher's appreciation of student's ability and effort, and en­
couragement students receive from one another. Each statement includes five
responses ranging from "Never" to "Always" scored on a five-point scale,
the total score of the questionnaire, which is the sum of the scores of all
three subscales, was used as an overall index of quality of instruction
for each of the three different treatments."
"The characteristics of each subscale and the whole questionnaire
are presented in Table 1. These include number of items, score range,[¬e]"

Page 53:
[¬s]"and reliability coefficients which were obtained on a sample of seventy-
three high school students."
"The observational technique used (see Appendix B) consists of three[¬e]"

Page 54:
[¬s]"different counts: (1) cues— a count of the number of times the teacher ex­
plains and clarifies a given concept to the students when he observes mis­
understanding by at least one student, (2) reinforcement— a count of the
number of times the teacher reinforces or criticizes students when they
respond to a question or a cue, and (3) participation— an index which is
based on multiplication of the two elements: the number of students
actively participating orally or by solving problems on the board and
the length of time of this on-going activity. When students are working
on assignments and the teacher is observing each individually, the observer
considers the situation to be one student participating multiplied by the
time the teacher spends with him."
"During the study, the same observer observed each group three to
five times during each learning task. The results of the observations were
then compared with the results from the quality of instruction questionnaire.
This technique was employed for observing all three groups in order to deter­
mine the differences in the use of the components among the groups. In the
enhanced CPR and mastery learning group only, the observer discussed his
observations with the teacher so that she could improve her use of cues,
participation and reinforcement. The feedback-corrective procedure, employed
by the two treatment groups, was reflected in the increase in achievement
from the formative test administered after each learning unit to the parallel
formative test administered after the corrective procedure.[¬e]"

[¬s]"Academic self-concept is the manner in which a student views his own

school.
The subscale (see .Appendix B) contains six items derived from a

The items relate to the student’s views of his own ability in the particular
subject area compared to that of his friends and classmates, and his views
of his own work in the specific content area."
"The higher the score
the more positive the student views his ability and work in the subject
area. The reliability coefficient obtained in a pilot study was found to

"Subject-related affect consists of the interests and attitudes which
a student develops and demonstrates in relation to a specific subject.[¬e]"

Page 58:

dent's feelings about the subject matter; his desire to take further
classes in this subject area, and his interest in the content area compared
to other content areas."
"The range of scoring the items extends
from the most negative response of 2 to the most positive response of 5.
The total score of the subscale is derived by the summation of all the
responses. The higher the score, the more positive are the feelings toward
the particular subject, while the lower the score the more negative are the
feelings toward the subject. The reliability coefficient obtained in a
pilot study was found to be + .66 and test-retest correlation (2 week

"Teacher-related affect is the attitude a student develops toward Ms
teacher in relation to the teacher's behavior, teacMng, and interactions."
"The teacher-related affect subscale (see Appendix B) is composed of

[¬s]"The scoring procedure is similar
to the procedures mentioned before. The responses to the negative state­
ment are reversed in the scoring. The higher the score on this subscale,

ability coefficient in the pilot study was found to be +.87 and test-retest
correlation (2-week interval) was +.83 (see Table 2)."
"Intellectual Achievement Respon­
sibility (IAR)
IAR is an attitude which relates to the more general concept of locus
of control. In the educational setting, this attitude relates to the way
students view their own success or failure in terms of taking responsibility
for educational outcomes. In this study, responsibility for success and
failure was directed to the two specific content areas being taught."
"The IAR questionnaire (Crandall, Katkovsky and Crandall, 1965; see
Appendix B) is aimed at assessing students' beliefs in reinforcement respon­
sibility exclusively in intellectual-academic achievement situations. The
IAR limits the sources of external control to those persons who most often
come into direct contact with the student: his parents, teachers, and peers.
The scale contains an equal number of positive and negative events. The
student's IAR scale is composed of 3*+ forced-choice items. We added to most
of the statements the specific subject of our interest in this study.[¬e]"

[¬s]"A student's 1+ score
is the sum of all positive events for which he assumes credit, and his I-
score is the sum of all negative events for which he assumes blame. His
total score (IAR) is the sum of his 1+ and I-. The IAR score range is 0
to 3*1. A low score indicates external intellectual achievement responsibility,
while a high score indicates internal intellectual achievement responsibility."
"Crandall, Katkovsky and Crandall (1965) report on test-retest
reliability (two-month interval) of .69 for total IAR, .66 for I+, and .7*1
for I- in third to fifth graders. For ninth graders the reliability was
.65 for total IAR, .*17 for 1+ and .69 for I-. The internal consistency of
I- and 1+ were computed separately. When eight even-numbered items of 1+
were correlated to nine odd-numbered items of I+, the correlation was .5*1.
The same procedure for I- items produced a correlation of .57 using the
Spearman-Brown Prophecy Formula. When older students were examined, the
correlation of both I- and 1+ increased to .60."
"School-related affect is considered a general attitude toward school
and school learning. It may also be termed as the student's interest in,
and likes and dislikes of various aspects of school."
"The school-related affect subscale (see Appendix B) contains nine items

example is: "I enjoy most of my school work and want to get as much additional

Page 11:
[¬s]"One purpose of
this study, then, was to attempt to answer Bloom's challenge:
. . . Under the best learning conditions we can devise (tutoring)
the average student is 2 sigma above the control average while
under mastery learning the average student is 1 sigma above the
control average. This is what I regard as the 2 sigma problem.
Can we devise practical learning conditions which will enable
students under group instruction to attain levels of achieve­
ment that we can at present reach only under good tutoring
condition (Bloom, 1981 in a letter to colleagues).
It was hoped that the maximal learning condition in our study would enable
students under group instruction to achieve as highly as do students under
tutoring.[¬e]"

References.Title: A method of group instruction which is as effective as one-to-one tutorial instruction.
References.Abstract: The major purpose of the research was to develop a group instruction method which is as effective as a one-to-one tutorial method, and, to determine the extent to which cognitive and affective outcomes of learning are affected by the instructional conditions provided to students. Three different group instructional conditions were used in the studies: (a) enhanced cues, participation, reinforcement, and feedback-corrective procedure, a maximal group instruction, (b) conventional group instruction, a minimal quality which is not equally adaptive to individual needs of most students, and (3) mastery learning, a quality which lies between the two extremes and uses the feedback-corrective procedure. Two studies were conducted in two different content areas and two grade levels. The results of the two studies indicate that the achievement students attain, the attitudes they acquire toward themselves as learners, and toward various aspects of school learning as well as the relations between prior and subsequent achievement are strongly determined by the instructional conditions provided to students. Seventy-four percent of students under maximal group instruction and 57 percent of the students under mastery learning conditions attained the level of final achievement reached only by the top 17 percent of the students under conventional instruction. Under maximal group instruction 69 percent of the students reached the mastery criterion (80 percent) on higher mental processes in comparison to 57 percent in the mastery learning and only 8 percent in the conventional groups. Large differences were also obtained on lower mental processes. The average student in the maximal group instruction was above 96 percent of the students in the conventional groups. In the enhanced CPR plus mastery learning and mastery learning groups the relation between prior and final achievement was very weak (about 8 percent common variance) however, under conventional conditions the relations remained strong (about 60 percent common variance). The effects of the instructional conditions on selected affective outcomes were also evident in the alteration of attitudes over the course of the study. Students under maximal group instruction became on the average, 22 percent more positive toward themselves as learners, the subject matter, teacher and school than were students under conventional instruction. The former were also more internal in taking responsibility for their learning outcomes. The mastery learning group advantage over the conventional group averaged 12 percent at the end of the study.
References.Comments: MDE: Please focus in extracting data for grade 9.  Code Compare Mastery learning versus Conventional. ESDE: Use Summative assessments (Table 5)  HMP (Higher mental processes) as primary and LMP (Lower mental processes) as secondary outcomes, post-test only.

ItemAttributeFullTextDetails.Text:
Page 2:
[¬s]"T
he purpose of school instruction is to provide
learning conditions that are optimal for all students.
The differences among individual students in their ante-
cedent cognitive characteristics, such as intelligence and
aptitude, are typically reflected in the students' final
cognitive outcomes (Bloom, 1976). This suggests that
instruction is basically biased toward a select group of
students characterized by high intelligence and high ap-
titude in the content area being studied.[¬e]"

Page 3:
[¬s]"Bloom (1976) has demonstrated that when instruction
was enhanced by an additional procedure of feedback
and correctives, the correlation between initial and final
achievement decreased from + .68 in the conventional
group to + .36 in the enhanced group. The reduction in
the relationship for the mastery learning group was due
in part to the correction of errors following each learning
task (increasing the homogeneity) and also to increasing
the specific CEB before each subsequent learning task.
The second purpose of this study was to examine the
extent to which the relationship between prior achieve-
ment and final achievement decreases under favorable in-
structional conditions. T[¬e]"

Codes.AdditionalText: posibly
