[¬s]"The idea shared by Carroll (1963), Dollard and Miller
(1950), and Bloom (1976) is that instruction must meet
the particular needs of each learner. The extent to which
cues, participation, reinforcement, and feedback-cor-
rectives are directed to individual learners' needs is an
indication of the quality of the instruction.[¬e]"

References.Title: The Effect of Quality of Instruction on Higher and Lower Mental Processes and on the Prediction of Summative Achievement
References.Abstract: The purpose of this research was to determine the extent to which lower and higher processes of cognitive outcomes of learning are affected by the instructional conditions provided to students. The research also attempted to examine the power of predictability of final outcomes by prior cognitive entry behavior under different qualities of instructional conditions.Two studies were conducted in two different content areas and two grade levels. Three different group instructional conditions were applied: (a) enhanced cues, participation, reinforcement, and feedback-corrective procedure (CPR + FB/C), (b) conventional instruction, and (c) mastery learning (ML).The results indicate that under CPR ² FB/C conditions most of the students (69%) reached mastery criterion as compared to 57% and 17% in the ML and conventional groups, respectively. The main differences occurred particularly in the higher mental processes rather than in the lower mental processes. The relation between prior and final achievemen...
References.Comments: MDE: Please code ML vs conventional instruction

Outcomes.Title: Algebra Test
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: F-value for comparison between treatment and control uploaded to Slack.

References.Title: Continuous progress advanced algebra in the Lincoln Public Schools - A study of achievement and attitude toward mathematic
References.Abstract:
The purpose of this study was to compare the achievement and attitude toward mathematics of students in continuous progress advanced algebra classes with the achievement of students in the traditional advanced algebra classes.  

Five teachers were involved, with two teachers teaching a total of five sections of continuous progress advanced algebra and three teachers teaching a total of five sections of traditional advanced algebra. All of the students were given pretests in achievement and attitude toward mathematics in September, 1969. They were given the same two tests as posttests when they finished the course. 

Student achievement in the continuous progress classes was not significantly different from student achievement in the traditional classes as measured by the Cooperative Mathematics Test, Algebra II, Form A.
References.Comments: ESDE: We can use the f-test from the ANCOVA as a measure of the difference between the control and intervention (f=0.203) - post-test adjusted, Co-operative Mathematics Test.
References.QuickCitation: Thomas Buren G (1972) Continuous progress advanced algebra in the Lincoln Public Schools - A study of achievement and attitude toward mathematic. , .

Page 11:
[¬s]"‘ Three consecutive numbers add up to 42. Find the numbers. ’ Many pupils would tackle this using a trial and improvement approach (in later years perhaps eventually with algebra), but in a Mathematics Mastery classroom much emphasis is placed on different representations of numbers and the connections between them. Bar modelling is a key approach that is explicitly taught (as early as Year 2 for appropriately simple problems) and MM pupils may well use this approach"
"Pupils will see that if the total is 42, the total without the ‘ ones ’ is 39 and if the three bars add up to 39, each bar is worth 39 ÷ 3 = 13. So the numbers are 13, 14 and 15. This can easily be checked: 13 + 14 + 15 = 42. The pupils’ fluency in making connections stems from their learning from the beginning of the programme: when dealing with number bonds in the first term of Y1 they are taught using a ‘ part, part, whole ’ model to appreciate that as they know 7 = 5 + 2, they also know 5 = 7 – 2, 2 = 7 – 5 etc. Much of the number work covered in the early years of Mathematics Mastery is material expected to be covered in the next year, for example Y2 pupils comfortably tackling Y3 objectives. The control condition was ‘ business as usual ’ during the intervention year (September 2012 to August 2013 for Cohort A and September 2013 to August 2014 for Cohort B). Control schools were then eligible to access the Mathematics Mastery programme after their year on the wait list had ended.[¬e]"

Page 7:
[¬s]"The Mathematics Mastery programme is a whole-school approach to teaching mathematics that aims to raise attainment for all pupils and close the attainment gap between pupils from low income families and their peers. The programme aims to deepen pupils’ conceptual understanding of key mathematical concepts.[¬e]"

[¬s]"Training and in-school support: headteachers, maths coordinators and class teachers receive 1 – 2 days of launch training, two in-school development visits, three multi-school cluster workshops, and access to an online toolkit with continuous professional development (CPD) resources, assessments and leadership frameworks.[¬e]"

Page 25:
[¬s]"The costs reported below come from information provided by Ark and have not been audited by the evaluation team. For two-form primary schools, there is an upfront cost of £6,000 for participating in the programme. (This is an ‘at cost’ price charged by Ark to cover basic infrastructure.) A total of seven days staff time is required for training: one day for the headteacher, two days for the head of maths, and two days for two maths teachers. To calculate the cost of headteachers’ time, we tak e the 20 th percentile of the headteacher pay scale in England and Wales (£56,027): 9 this is then divided by 230 (the approximate number of working days in a year) to give a headteacher day rate of £243. 10 We then inflate this figure by a fifth to allow for other costs not directly incorporated into headteachers’ salaries ( such as employer contributions to pensions) giving a total cost of £292. 11 Analogous calculations were made for the head of maths (two days training at a final day rate of £196) 12 and the class teachers (a total of four days training at a final day rate of £141). 13 Total training costs therefore amount to £1,248. The[¬e]"

Page 26:
[¬s]"total cost to the primary school is £7,248 for this first year. We then estimate the average number of pupils affected per primary school as 57 — the number of pupils initially enrolled into the primary trial (5,108) divided the number of primary schools initially enrolled (90). The ‘per pupil’ cost of delivering the primary school intervention was therefore £127 for the first year. In subsequent years schools are able to opt for different pathways depending on the amount of support and training they wish to choose; they also have ongoing access to the curriculum materials for additional year groups. The per pupil cost therefore reduces considerably, to below £30 per pupil for additional year groups.[¬e]"

Page 12:
[¬s]"The Number Knowledge Test (NKT) was used to examine children’s skills in maths . 5 This is an individually administered oral test that takes about 10 minutes to complete, and requires only a few basic props (counters of two contrasting colours, visual displays with numbers). This test in particular was chosen as it was appropriate for reception age children and could be conducted orally.[¬e]"

Page 14:
[¬s]"It is important to note that for this trial we were unable to ask for permission to link to the National Pupil Database. This means we do not have individual-level data to provide us with the characteristics of students, such as whether they were eligible for Free School Meals or their gender. Hence we are unable to undertake sub-analyses by gender or by FSM status.[¬e]"

Outcomes.Title: The Number Knowledge Test (NKT)
Outcomes.OutcomeDescription: The Number Knowledge Test (NKT) examines children’s skills in maths.This is an individually administered oral test that takes about 10 minutes to complete. The test was administered by external testers from NatCen Social Research. Total raw scores obtained across the whole of the Number Knowledge test was used.

References.Title: Mathematics Mastery: Primary Evaluation Report
References.Abstract: The Mathematics Mastery programme is a whole-school approach to teaching mathematics that aims to raise attainment for all pupils and close the attainment gap between pupils from low income families and their peers. The programme aims to deepen pupils’ understanding of key mathematical concepts. Compared to traditional curricula, fewer topics are covered in more depth and greater emphasis is placed on problem solving and on encouraging mathematical thinking. This evaluation assessed the impact of Mathematics Mastery on pupils in Year 1, after the programme had been implemented in schools for one year. It was intended that schools would also begin to use the programme in Year 2 in the second year of implementation, and continue until the approach was in place across the school. Eighty-three schools from London and the South East participated in the trial, with a total sample of 4,176 pupils. Participating schools received training and resources to support the adoption of the programme which was delivered by the education charity Ark.
References.Comments: Please note there are two documents attached. One is the EEF Primary maths mastery trial report. The other is the overarching summary report across both primary and secondary trials. Please focus only on the primary school trial for this data extraction.
References.Authors: Vignoles Anna ; Jerrim John ; Cowan Richard ;
References.QuickCitation: Vignoles Anna, Jerrim John, and Cowan Richard (2015) Mathematics Mastery: Primary Evaluation Report. London: ,  DOI: https://doi.org/10.13140/RG.2.1.5064.4729

Following review or restudy of the instructional materials, the student was retested with a parallel form of the unit achievement test. This recycling could continue for a maximum of three times before the student was promoted to the next unit.[¬e]"

References.Title: Mastery versus nonmastery instruction with varying test item feedback treatments
References.Abstract: Used a 3 * 2 * 2 factorial design with factors of feedback specificity (total, partial, or none), instructional strategy (mastery or nonmastery), and mental ability (high and low scores on Otis-Lennon Mental Ability Test). 116 male high school students were Ss for the 5-wk study. The mastery strategy was superior in terms of immediate and delayed achievement, but Ss required 50% more time to complete instructions with no difference in attitude. Partial item feedback for unit tests was superior on both immediate achievement and attitude with no difference in retention. A mastery strategy with partial item feedback appears most desirable when time trade-off is justifiable. (26 ref.) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2010 APA, all rights reserved).

References.Title: A study of mastery learning and its effects on achievement of sixth grade social studies students
References.Abstract: The purpose of this study was to compare the effects on achievement of using a mastery learning strategy for teaching selected anthropological concepts to sixth grade social studies students with the effects of using a more conventional classroom teaching strategy for teaching selected anthropological concepts to sixth grade social studies students. Methods and Procedure: two intact classes of 26 children each used the teach-test-reteach-retest feedback/correction process (mastery learning strategy) while two other intact classes of 27 and 28 each were taught by conventional methods which did not utilize the mastery learning strategy. Materials developed by The Anthropology Curriculum Project, University of Georgia, 1972, were used by the children and teachers involved in the study.  A 70% median score was required in each experimental group before the total group could progress to the next selected anthropological concept. Peer tutoring was primarily used for the reteaching section of the teach-test-reteach-retest (mastery learning) strategy of teaching. The hypotheses were examined by analysis of variance considering treatment by sex, by IQ, and by reading level with the anthropology achievement test score as the dependent variable. Use of the two-way factorial design allowed for testing of interaction between independent variables. The .05 level of significance was used to,accept or reject the various hypotheses. Results: the experimental method of teaching produced superior effects with male students. The mastery learning strategy of teaching had a decidedly positive effect upon low reading level students and upon low IQ students. The experimental method of teaching had no differential effect upon high reading level students, upon high IQ students, or upon female students. Conclusions: no significant differences at the .05 level were obtained on the overall comparison between mean achievement scores from those students receiving mastery learning treatment and from the students who did not receive mastery learning treatment.

References.Title: The effects of level of cognitive achievement on selected learning criteria under mastery learning and normal classroom instruction.
References.Abstract:
The central problem of this study is "Do the two groups of students under mastery learning and normal classroom instruction who reach the same criterion level of learning as measured by an achievement test show much the same similarity on other learning criteria?" The learning criteria this study uses are the retention of the learned material on a relatively short term basis, transfer of this material to subject related novel situations, lower and higher mental processes attained or used in the process of learning, and positive affect and interest in the learning task.  The research for this study was done in two settings. The micro study was done in two middle class, white Chicago area high schools, whereas the macro studies were done in four Chicago area city colleges. Each of these two settings will be discussed separately. 
Micro Study: this study was done in two white middle class high schools in the Chicago area, and included 5 ninth grade beginning algebra classes of 138 students. At the end of instruction  the students took a final summative test on the chapter prepared by the writer of the text with the cooperation of the researcher. This test had 20 items, 15 of which were lower mental process and 5 of which were higher mental process items. The criterion level was set on these 20 items. In addition 10 items were constructed to measure transfer. A three way analysis of variance of level of learning, aptitude or time, and the kind of instruction was performed using the four learning criteria as the dependent variables. The correlations of level of learning and the learning criterion in each hypothesis, time or aptitude and the learning criterion, and finally the multiple correlations of level of learning and time or aptitude on the learning criterion for each hypothesis were obtained.  When the means of the criterion groups were compared with each other on the summative test, there were no significant differences among the groups.
Macro Study: this study was conducted in 4 Chicago area Junior Colleges, three of these having a majority of black students (about 90%), and one having primarily white students (about 90%). Altogether 433 students participated in the study. The subject areas included Biology 103, 111, Mathematics 103, History 103, Psychology 103, and Spanish 103. There were altogether 16 classes in the study, 8 of these were mastery learning classes, and 8 others served as control classes.  The students' grade point averages were obtained as a general index of scholastic ability.  Level of learning was measured by a summative test given at the end of the course. This test was composed of lower and higher mental process items. The criterion level of learning was set at 70% mastery of the material. In five of the eight studies, the mastery classes as a whole did better on their summative test scores than the control classes, in three of them significantly so. 
Both the results of the micro and macro studies show without a single exception that students who reach the criterion level on lower mental process items score significantly better on higher mental process items compared to students who have not reached this level.
References.Comments: Please focus in comparing scores between the ML & Control group at the macro study (4 schools).
References.QuickCitation: Yildiran Guzver (1977) The effects of level of cognitive achievement on selected learning criteria under mastery learning and normal classroom instruction.. , The University of Chicago.

This test had 20 items, 15 of which were lower mental process and 5 of which were higher mental process items. The criterion level was set on these 20 items. In addition 10 items were constructed to measure transfer. A three way analysis of variance of level of learning, aptitude or time, and the kind of instruction was performed using the four learning criteria as the dependent variables. The correlations of level of learning and the learning criterion in each hypothesis, time or aptitude and the learning criterion, and finally the multiple correlations of level of learning and time or aptitude on the learning criterion for each hypothesis were obtained. When the means of the criterion groups were compared with each other on the summative test, there were no significant differences among the groups. Macro Study: this study was conducted in 4 Chicago area Junior Colleges, three of these having a majority of black students (about 90%), and one having primarily white students (about 90%). Altogether 433 students participated in the study. The subject areas included Biology 103, 111, Mathematics 103, History 103, Psychology 103, and Spanish 103. There were altogether 16 classes in the study, 8 of these were mastery learning classes, and 8 others served as control classes. The students' grade point averages were obtained as a general index of scholastic ability. Level of learning was measured by a summative test given at the end of the course. This test was composed of lower and higher mental process items. The criterion level of learning was set at 70% mastery of the material. In five of the eight studies, the mastery classes as a whole did better on their summative test scores than the control classes, in three of them significantly so. Both the results of the micro and macro studies show without a single exception that students who reach the criterion level on lower mental process items score significantly better on higher mental process items compared to students who have not reached this level.
